xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline><author><person><nameText>Penelope Kilby</nameText></person></author></nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THIS week marked the official start to the bushfire season in NSW and with more than 1000 fires burning throughout the month of September, fire authorities have urged home and land owners to prepare their properties for a dry, hot summer.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Police and Emergency Services Minister Michael Gallacher said the fire season, which began on Tuesday, was off to a hot start.</p><p>'In the last few weeks we have already seen significant fire activity, which has put homes and lives at risk,' he said.</p><p>'Last season was a challenging one in NSW, with more than 50 homes destroyed in January alone.'</p><p>NSW Rural Fire Service (RFS) commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons said the Bushfire Co-operative Research Centre's (BCRC) predictions of above average fire conditions this season were a timely reminder of the risks of bush and grass fires and highlighted the importance of early preparation.</p><p>Mr Fitzsimmons said more than 40 per cent of people surveyed last year across some of the worst affected areas last summer ' including Coonabarabran, Yass and the Shoalhaven ' said they wished they had done more preparation and 35pc wished they had a better plan.</p><p>'This increased fire activity has brought forward the start of the official bushfire danger period for many areas of the State, including Tamworth, Taree, Upper Hunter and Shoalhaven,' he said.</p><p>'Regardless of where you live in NSW, even a normal Australian bushfire season is dangerous.'</p><p>NSWRFS deputy commissioner Rob Rogers said weather conditions would be drier and warmer than previously predicted.</p><p>'We've had a very busy start to spring, and we're only a month in,' Mr Rogers said.</p><p>'Traditionally there are a lot of fires this time of year, but not to this extent.</p><p>'This is the most number of fires we've had in a decade.'</p><p>Mr Rogers said fire agencies had done all the preparation they could and said home owners and land owners needed to do their bit.</p><p>He said it was important to clear gutters, maintain gardens and have a hose that reaches right around the home.</p><p>'By and large land owners know what they are doing.'</p><p>A BCRC spokesperson said above average rainfall for much of the past three years was likely to continue the trend of heavy grass fuel loads throughout the grassland areas of NSW.</p><p>'These grassland areas include those west of the Great Dividing Range, the Northern Tablelands and the Upper Hunter,' the spokesperson said.</p><p>'Across much of the forested areas of NSW, below average rainfall since July has resulted in a drying trend in forest fuels.</p><p>'If this continues, above normal fire activity conditions are expected for the forested areas of central and southern NSW coast and ranges.'</p><p>Bureau of Meteorology manager of NSW climate services Aaron Coutts-Smith said the outlook still stood in terms of 'seeding' risk, which indicated above average potential for fire.</p><p>'Interestingly, we had two back to back La Ni??a events which led to increased fire activity, so it appeared to be significant, but we have definitely seen worse fire seasons,' Mr Coutts-Smith said.</p><p>'If we look west of the ranges now, most of it is grass fire risk, thanks to the June rain.</p><p>'East of the ranges it is more forest fire prone.'</p><p>Mr Coutts-Smith said the most worrying source of fire was dry lightning in the early part of the fire season.</p><p>He said it was useful for people to be aware of their area and its conditions.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:58J0-YVG1-JD6G-4380-00000-00<published>2013-03-14T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline><author><person><nameText>Brooke Ormes</nameText></person></author></nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">PROFESSOR Lesley Hughes from the Australian Climate Commission gave a talk at Bega's St John's Anglican Church on Monday night about the effects of climate change on the South East. </p><p>Professor Hughes is an ecologist in the Department of Biological Sciences at Macquarie University and an expert on the impacts of climate change on species and ecosystems.</p><p>Almost 70 people attended the forum, which also featured Clean Energy For Eternity's Matthew Nott and Bega Valley Shire Mayor Bill Taylor as guest speakers. </p><p>In introducing Professor Hughes, Dr Nott reminded attendees about the unprecedented January heatwave and spoke about the ACC's recent report The Angry Summer. </p><p>'As a farming community, a coastal community and a rural community we are very vulnerable to the effects of climate change in the region,' he said. </p><p>'We've just experienced the hottest January on record, including the hottest day in Bega ever recorded on January 18.'</p><p>Professor Hughes' presentation took in much of what is contained in The Angry Summer report, but focused on the increased risk of bushfire and low rainfall that climate change presents in the South East. </p><p>'Due to warming trends the forest fire danger index in Australia has increased most in the South East and the hazard reduction time has decreased,' she said. </p><p>'This is already impacting on your region, as you have seen this summer.'</p><p>Professor Hughes also talked about the effects climate change may have on the dairy and forestry industries in the South East. </p><p>'There are positives in the prediction models, less frost and longer growing seasons, but these are outnumbered by the negatives, primarily low water availability and increased heat stress for livestock.</p><p>'The big unknown for forestry, however, is how pests and diseases will affect trees in a warmer world.'</p><p>The effect of climate change on health was another topic that engaged the audience. </p><p>Professor Hughes ended her talk by saying, 'The truth we must all face about our planet is that it's finite and we need to take better care of it.'</p><p>The question and answer session that followed sparked a lively debate about the role of local government. </p><p>Cr Taylor highlighted the many ways in which the BVSC is meeting the challenges of climate change including the solar panels on Bega library and the many studies into impacts on estuaries and wetlands by the council.</p><p>'We as a council accept the science, it's a serious issue for our local community, however we are a creature of state government and we limited in what we can do,' he said. </p><p>Professor Hughes disagreed and said local government had an enormous role to play. </p><p>'Individually you can't do much, but collectively you can do a tremendous amount,' she said. </p><p>'You can bring about change and that starts with local government, and in the community they need to be the point of focus of education about climate change.'</p><p>For more information about the Australian Climate Commission or to download The Angry Summer report, visit <url normalizedValue="http://www.climatecommission.gov.au">www.climatecommission.gov.au</url>.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata Experts estimate that the chances of it happening are millions to one. Only five other such cases have been documented worldwide.</p><p>Thousands axed</p><p>JAKARTA: Fifty companies have told the Indonesian Government they will lay off thousands of workers as the economic crisis and forest fire disaster begin to bite into profits. An estimated two million day workers are already out of work.</p><p>Solidarity in power</p><p>WARSAW: Poland's new Solidarity-led coalition cabinet won a confidence motion in parliament early yesterday, clearing the last hurdle to establish itself in office.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:3SJJ-4PM0-0048-T3WH-00000-00<published>1997-09-25T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Australian General News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"> SYDNEY, Sept 25 AAP - The New South Wales government today offered to send firefighters to Indonesia to help battle forest fires that had created a smog crisis in the region.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Emergency Services Minister Bob Debus said he had written to the Australian Ambassador in Indonesia informing him that the NSW Rural Fire Service was ready to help fight the fires.</p><p>"It is not an overstatement to claim that the NSW Rural Fire Service is a world leader in rural and forest fire suppression and management," Mr Debus said in a statement.</p><p> "Their outstanding effort during the January 1994 bushfires stands as clear testimony to their expertise."</p><p> He said NSW fire fighters already had helped Indonesian authorities twice before, in 1991 and 1994.</p><p>Indonesia has been criticised by Malaysia and Singapore because smoke from forest fires in Borneo and Sumatra has cast a pall over those two countries for months and sent air pollution indexes to unhealthy levels.</p><p> The fires have destroyed more than 80,000 hectares of land, with the status of up to 300,000ha unknown, and forced the closure of several airports in the region.</p><p> About 20 million Indonesians are directly affected by the smoke.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1997</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SJJ-4PM0-0048-T3WH-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="201"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1997 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:44JN-CN30-0197-X267-00000-00<published>2000-11-26T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">IN BRIEF Riot pay-off</p><p nitf:lede="true">HUNDREDS of thousands of dollars in workers' compensation has been paid to prison officers caught up in the 1999 Christmas Day Casuarina riot. Other staff, including an infirmary nurse who was so traumatised she had to leave the prison service, have received lump-sum payouts.</p><p>At least one prison officer is pursuing a District Court claim which could be worth hundreds of thousands of dollars.</p><p> Girl 'critical'</p><p>A 16-YEAR-OLD Derby teenager is fighting for her life in Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital after being savagely bashed. She was attacked at the Karmalinunga Reserve, Derby, on Friday night. Police were called after a complaint and found the woman unconscious with severe head injuries. Her 25-year-old de- facto was arrested and is in custody charged with assault causing bodily harm. He will appear in Broome Court tomorrow.</p><p> Forest fire</p><p>A BUSHFIRE has burnt out about 80 hectares of mixed jarrah forest near Serpentine National Park, about 80km south of Perth. The area was evacuated yesterday afternoon after the fire started at about midday.</p><p> Twin trouble</p><p>THE father of Brisbane's siamese twins faces jail after allegedly riding a motorcycle without a licence. Shane Jeffery Conyard, 23, was disqualified for three months on July 28 after pleading guilty to two counts of unlicensed driving, and is alleged to have re-offended on October 20.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:458W-TD40-0197-F3MS-00000-00<published>1996-01-05T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>COSTELLO D</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">KEYWORD-HIT</p><p nitf:lede="true">APEC bid</p><p nitf:lede="true">COLOMBO: Sri Lanka had applied to join the 18-nation Asia Pacific</p><p nitf:lede="true">Economic Co-operation forum to gain stronger economic bargaining power,</p><p nitf:lede="true">Media Minister Dharmasiri Senanayake said yesterday. He said Sri Lanka</p><p nitf:lede="true">was the first country in the South Asian Association for Regional</p><p nitf:lede="true">Co-operation to apply to join APEC.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Nuke fear</p><p>TOKYO: Pakistani Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto said in an interview</p><p>published yesterday by a Japanese newspaper that India ""must be</p><p>restrained" if the subcontinent was to avoid a nuclear showdown. She</p><p>told the Yomiuri Shimbun that Pakistan and India should join the</p><p>Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.</p><p>UN warns</p><p>NEW YORK: The United Nations yesterday called on the international</p><p>community to take urgent action to prevent Burundi from slipping into</p><p>all-out civil war. UN spokesman Sylvana Foa said the world should not</p><p>wait until the situation became a ""raging forest fire". The UN has</p><p>called for a border standby force to be based in neighbouring Zaire and</p><p>for monitoring guards inside Burundi.</p><p>Libya ban</p><p>WASHINGTON: United States President Bill Clinton yesterday extended US</p><p>economic sanctions against Libya because of what he said was its</p><p>continued sponsorship of international terrorism. The sanctions, first</p><p>imposed 10 years ago by former President Ronald Reagan for Libya's</p><p>alleged involvement in terrorism, would have lapsed had Mr Clinton not</p><p>acted.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:44HJ-SM80-015G-X50F-00000-00<published>2001-11-26T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>OPINION; Pg. 19</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>CHRIS BRICE</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Selected items from The Advertiser, published during the past 100 years. Compiled by CHRIS BRICE.</p><p nitf:lede="true">1901 (November 26)</p><p nitf:lede="true">AT the meeting of the city council . . . a letter was received from representatives of various musical and other societies . . . expressing their appreciation of the great improvements made in connection with the seating accommodation of the Town Hall by the erection of the handsome dress circle and organ galleries.</p><p>The letter continued: ". . . We are pleased to hear that it is likely that this fine hall will be lit with electric light. If this is done it will greatly improve the lighting and do away with the heat caused by the gas, as well as, in our opinion, make your concert hall one of the best, if not the best, in the Southern Hemisphere.</p><p> 1926 (November 27)</p><p>IN addition to a specifically designed set piece for the Henley-on-Torrens carnival in coloured lacework, a representation of a forest fire, silvery Satanic revolving wheels, a lattice diamond, batteries of electric Roman candles and streamers, shells, golden rains, comet and electric stars . . . and a host of other unique fireworks will be well worth the patronage that Adelaide's greatest water carnival always claims. Two trick clowns, Punch and Judy, and the slippery dip will keep the children amused and rowing, head to head and hand balancing displays, diving, together with other items of interest, and numerous sideshows, will keep grown-ups interested.</p><p> 1951 (November 29)</p><p>WHEN twin diesel electric locomotives hauled the Overland express - Australia's finest train - for the first time from Adelaide last night, thousands of people cheered and waved from stations, crossings and overway bridges between the city and Aldgate. The leading locomotive's four powerful air-horns acknowledged each railside group's greeting.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:44KP-Y1P0-0197-F4XM-00000-00<published>2000-11-24T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>OUTDOORS; Pg. D11</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>Philip Hammond</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">WONDERFUL Dividing Range scenery awaits the leisure motorist a couple of hours' drive north of Brisbane.</p><p nitf:lede="true">As if the drive north of Kilcoy toward the Conondale Range National Park and Kenilworth State Forest is not pleasant enough, the jewel is further on.</p><p>Drive past the climbable forest-fire lookout tower at Jimna, 16km toward Murgon, and you'll find the entrance to LandCruiser Mountain Park.</p><p>With its great bush camping spots along the creek and network of tracks to tempt novices through to the most adventurous four-wheel-drivers, LandCruiser Park is well worth a stop over, even for two-wheel-drive vehicles.</p><p>The park is Alben and Helen Perrett's working cattle property and the scene of periodic club rallies and motorised gymkhanas.</p><p>Opposite the park's entrance, following the flow of Yabba Creek toward Lake Borumba, is one of the best little dirt road drives of the region. This twisting, switchback byway is called -- no kidding -- the Mount Buggery Road.</p><p>If you want some fun motoring, head for the coast along this tree-lined corridor. One minute you're fishtailing on a muddy corner, the next you are high on a ridge with superb views of Lake Borumba and the surrounding forests.</p><p>Then it's down over the Kandanga Ranges for a couple of shallow creek crossings at Derriers Flat before emerging in the quiet little township of Imbil. This is the southern stop for the Valley Rattler steam train which runs from Gympie.</p><p>From there, it's a choice of north to Gympie, across to Noosa and the Sunshine Coast, or back south down the Bruce Highway.</p><p>Information: LandCruiser Mountain Park camping -- 2WD vehicles $17 a night (24-hour stay) or $28 for 4WDs. BYO drinking water. (07) 5497 3164.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49N3-RP30-01S8-C267-00000-00<published>1992-12-22T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Efficient new tankers set to tackle fire dangers WITH the threat of bushfires in Tasmania now a serious concern, the Forestry Commission yesterday unveiled the latest addition to its forest fire-fighting team - the new multi-use heavy tanker.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The tanker is the sixth unit of its kind to be built in Tasmania by the commission and will be used as a replacement for the commission's old Bedford tankers.</p><p>The tankers are unique because their 3800-litre water tank is interchangeable with other body applications such as tippers or trays.</p><p>The Forestry Commission's fire equipment officer, Mr Tim Geard, said both the commission and the Tasmanian Fire Service had a fleet of 20 to 30-year-old tankers which had travelled only 15,000 kilometres in 20 years.</p><p>"They are notoriously unreliable because they are underused," he said.</p><p>"The new trucks we have virtually pay for themselves because they can be used for plantation projects and minor road work.</p><p>"The new tankers are probably no different from the old trucks in fire-fighting capacity but in terms of getting to the fire and efficiency they are much better." Mr Geard said there were still seven dedicated tankers in service which would be replaced.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>Mr Vic Miller, a Forestry Commission mechanic , gives the thumbs-up tothe new tankers.920MX6702/17</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:49KR-WMB0-01S8-C1CB-00000-00<published>1988-09-16T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">IN BRIEF China aid to US CHINA is donating 200 fire extinguishers and sending experts to help fight a two-month-old blaze in Yellowstone National Park. A US Embassy spokeswoman said the donation was thought to be the first time China had given aid to the United States.</p><p>The People's Daily said the high-quality pneumatic extinguishers were effective in fighting a huge forest fire in northeast China in 1987 which killed nearly 200 people.</p><p>Sri Lanka bid INDIA has announced a five-day ceasefire beginning today in Sri Lanka where its troops are fighting Tamil guerillas. Indian troops will halt their offensive against the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam to enable the rebels to lay down arms and take part in elections proposed in the island's north and east.</p><p>$28,000 cab fare THE London taxi travelling from London to Sydney as a bicentennial event has arrived in New Delhi after encountering Afghan rebels blazing away with rifles and receiving a full military escort across the Indo-Pakistan border. One of the taxi's meters, running at London rates, shows a fare of 13,000 ($A28,200), while the other has clocked up $15,368 at Sydney rates. The six-strong team in the taxi expedition left London on August 19.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:49K3-JP20-01S8-G1G3-00000-00<published>1987-05-12T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>COSTELLO D</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Israeli split looms JERUSALEM._ Israel's divided national unity Cabinet opens a crucial debate today on a Middle East peace conference, with the Foreign Minister, Mr Peres, set to force an early general election if his proposals are blocked.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Mr Peres said he would propose to the decision-making inner Cabinet that Israel take part in a conference as an opening to peace negotiations with Jordan. Terrorists warn US BEIRUT._ The Abu Nidal dissident Palestinian group has warned the United States against extraditing to Israel, or ill-treating, one of its members arrested by US officials at New York's Kennedy International Airport on May 6. Rugby tour claim denied WELLINGTON._ The New Zealand Rugby Union last night denied accusations by the Prime Minister, Mr Lange, that another rebel tour of South Africa would follow the forthcoming World Cup tournament. Mr Lange said yesterday the 16-nation event would end with a World Cup side leaving for a play-off against the Springboks. Chinese blaze kills 119 BEIJING._ The death toll in a huge forest fire in north-eastern China had risen to 119, with 102 people injured and some 51,000 homeless, the China Daily newspaper reported yesterday. Satellite photographs showed 300,000 ha of destroyed forest.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4GT1-3GR0-015G-X2GM-00000-00<published>2005-08-05T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES; Pg. 95</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>By STAN JAMES</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The Crossing Guard ***</p><p nitf:lede="true">1995, noon, Seven</p><p nitf:lede="true">Jack Nicholson rises above his charismatic persona as Freddy Gale, a pathetic time bomb of emotional self-destruction, out of control. Writer-director Sean Penn has created a confronting and riveting story of a tragedy, its destructive path and the arduous healing process. Gale has never recovered from the death, eight years earlier, of his daugher, killed by a drunk driver. Today the driver is released.</p><p>Scent of a Woman ***</p><p>1992, 8pm, Showtime Greats/Foxtel</p><p>Al Pacino is at his impressive best in the role which won him the best actor Oscar. He shows despair, frustration, humanity and brilliance as blind, retired army officer Frank Slade. Into his life comes raw student Charlie Sims (Chris O'Donnell, showing perception) to "babysit" him for a weekend. Slade talks Sims into an indulgent weekend in New York, and each learns much about other's life.</p><p>Home Alone ***</p><p>1990, 8.30pm, Seven</p><p>One of the most popular films of all time, an improbable story of little Kevin, played with gusto and charm by Macaulay Culkin, who is accidentally left home by his family as they rush off on holiday. After a slow buildup, under director Chris Columbus (Harry Potter's Philosopher's Stone  and Chamber of Secrets ) it turns into slapstick farce as two thieves (Joe Pesci and Daniel Stern) try to rob the house and meet the force of Kevin's tricks and traps. Meanwhile, mum (Catherine O'Hara), dad (John Heard) and family desperately try to solve the crisis.</p><p>Firestorm *</p><p>1998, 10.45pm, Seven</p><p>Oscar-winning cinematographer Dean Semler's uninspiring directorial debut isn't helped by former American football star Howie Long as Wyoming firefighter Jesse Graves, leader of a team of smoke-jumpers who parachute into forest fires. During a forest fire, a killer (William Forsythe) escapes from prison and joins convicts fighting the blaze, aiming to grab $36 million in stashed loot. Scott Glenn is a firefighter who discovers the escape as a firestorm is created.</p><p>Phantasm III: Lord of the</p><p> Dead *</p><p>1994, 12.25am, Seven</p><p>Third dreary entry in the horror series. Michael Baldwin and Reggie Bannister are back as Mike and Reggie, who join with Jody (Bill Thornbury, from beyond the dead, in an effort to stop the dreaded Tall Man (Angus Scrimm).</p><p>RATINGS **** Outstanding,  *** High quality, ** Competent,  * Minor interest</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4GNH-0T80-00VK-216Y-00000-00<published>2005-07-18T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>International News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Highlights of the AAP world wire at 15:00 July 18</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p/><p nitf:lede="true">Highlights of the AAP world file since 03:00<br/><br/>TO COME:<br/>ASIA: Adelaide man admits to being hash addict in Indon court<br/>    GIANYAR, Bali, July 18, AAP - An Adelaide man facing up to 10 years in a Bali prison for possession of hashish has admitted he is a recovering addict who still uses the drug to relieve stress (INDON PYLE upcoming)<br/><br/>OTHER MAIN WORLD NEWS:<br/><br/>ASIA: Indon MP's question Farmer appointment<br/>    JAKARTA, July 18 AAP - The chief of the Indonesian parliament's foreign affairs committee today added his voice to concerns about Australia's plan to appoint former Immigration Department head Bill Farmer as Canberra's next ambassador to Jakarta.   (INDON FARMER sent at 14:40, 608 words.)<br/><br/>UK: Khan was the likely leader of London bomb four</p><p nitf:lede="true">LONDON, July 18 AFP - Mohammad Sidique Khan, the eldest of the four London bombers - whose family says he was "brainwashed" into terrorism - has been singled out in the British media as the likely leader of the operation. (UK KHAN Backgrounder sent at 14:07, 649 words.)</p><p>MID:Iraq war boosted al-Qaeda, made Britain vulnerable to attack</p><p>LONDON, July 18 AFP - The war in Iraq gave a "boost" to al-Qaeda and made Britain especially vulnerable to attacks like those of July 7 in London, a respected British research centre says. (UK BLASTS RESEARCH sent at 14:09, 528 words.)<br/><br/>MID: Iraq in suicide bomb blitz; Saddam faces first charges</p><p>AL-MUSAYYIB, Iraq, July 18 Agencies - More than 110 Iraqis were killed and 300 wounded in a three-day suicide bombing blitz as justice officials lifted the curtain on the trial of ousted dictator Saddam Hussein. (IRAQ Nightlead (With factbox) sent at 14:07, 527 words.)<br/><br/>UK: Tributes pour in for 'political giant' Edward Heath</p><p>LONDON, July 18 AFP - Tributes have poured in for Sir Edward Heath following the former British prime minister's death yesterday. He was 89. (UK HEATH TRIBUTES sent at 14:41, 489 words.)<br/><br/>CAM: Mexico evacuates Caribbean coast, offshore oil platforms</p><p>CANCUN, Mexico, July 17 AP - Winds of 235kph from Hurricane Emily lashed Cancun's beaches today after thousands of tourists were evacuated. (EMILY Nightlead sent at 14:07, 350 words.)<br/><br/>EUR: Raging Spanish forest fire kills 12 firefighters</p><p>SANTA MARIA DEL ESPINO, Spain, July 18 Reuters - At least a dozen firefighters were killed when they were trapped by a forest fire raging along a 17-kilometre front in central Spain. (SPAIN FIRES Nightlead sent at 14:07, 387 words.)<br/><br/>PAC: Passengers stranded as Air NZ strike begins</p><p>AUCKLAND, July 18 AAP/NZPA - Six flights between Australia and New Zealand were cancelled today as the first day of a strike by Air New Zealand cabin crew took effect. (NZ AIRNZ 2nd Lead sent at 13:53, 324 words.)<br/><br/>EUR: Indonesia, Aceh rebels agree peace deal in Helsinki</p><p>HELSINKI, July 17 AFP - The Indonesian government and rebels have reached a groundbreaking agreement to end 30 years of fighting in Aceh province and a memorandum of understanding will be formally signed next month, both sides said today. (INDON ACEH Daylead Corrected Repeat sent at 12:41, 647 words.)<br/><br/>UK: Pigeons fattened on fast food throwaways</p><p>LONDON, July 18 PA - Fast food rubbish on Britain's streets is creating overweight "super pigeons", that rely on waste to survive, anti-litter campaigners warned today. (UK PIGEONS sent at 12:29, 372 words.)<br/><br/>UK: Polanski sues publishers over sexual advances claim</p><p>LONDON, July 18 PA - Roman Polanski's libel action over an allegation he propositioned a woman following the horrific murder of his film star wife begins at London's High Court today. (UK POLANSKI sent at 12:22, 334 words.)<br/><br/>US: FBI says has files on Greenpeace, other rights groups</p><p>WASHINGTON, July 17 AP - The FBI has thousands of pages of records in its files relating to the monitoring of civil rights, environmental and similar advocacy groups, the Justice Department acknowledges. (US FBI sent at 12:02, 479 words.)<br/><br/>ASIA: Corby's flashy saviour says he can pull win out of the bag</p><p>JAKARTA, July 18 AAP - His picture-heavy walls are lined with lawmakers and lesbians, and his chubby, diamond-studded fingers wave frantically as he regales visitors with tales of his romps with Sydney prostitutes. (INDON CORBY HUTAPEA (AAP Backgroundr, with file pix) sent at 11:53, 880 words.)<br/><br/>ASIA: North Korea nuclear talks to start July 26 says paper</p><p>SEOUL, July 18 Reuters - Stalled six-party talks aimed at ending North Korea's nuclear weapons programs will begin on July 26 in Beijing, a South Korean daily reported today. (NUCLEAR KOREA sent at 14:09, 222 words.)<br/><br/>US: Study says ethanol not worth the energy</p><p>ALBANY, New York, July 17 AP - Farmers, businesses and state officials in the US are investing millions of dollars in ethanol and biofuel plants as renewable energy sources, but a new study says the alternative fuels burn more energy than they produce. (US ETHANOL sent at 10:47, 496 words.)<br/><br/>US: Disneyland celebrates 50th anniversary in style</p><p>ANAHEIM, California, July 17 AP - Thousands of Disney fans donned special gold-coloured Mickey ears as they streamed through the entrance to Disneyland today, 50 years after the landmark opened its gates and gave birth to the modern theme park. (US DISNEYLAND sent at 09:33, 494 words.)<br/><br/>AFR: 60 dead in Equatorial Guinea plane crash: president</p><p>MALABO, July 17 AFP - Sixty people were killed when a Russian-built Antonov plane crashed in flames in Equatorial Guinea shortly after takeoff from the capital Malabo, President Teodoro Obiang Nguema said today. (EGUINEA PLANE Second Daylead sent at 09:23, 656 words.)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:54PJ-J6N1-DXHW-F14D-00000-00<published>2009-02-20T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>A</positionSection><positionSequence>Pg. 13</positionSequence></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline><author><person><nameText>The Queanbeyan Age</nameText></person></author></nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">22 February 2008 It was just another day at the office for the Snowy Hydro SouthCare helicopter crew, but for Queanbeyan High School student Nathan Burgess it was a day he will never forget. The 15-year-old became the 3000th rescue- mission performed by SouthCare after a family trip to Tallaganda State Forest last Sunday went horribly wrong.</p><p>A Queanbeyan woman came home to find her mother in the street and their family house up in flames last Friday. An electrical fault sparked a devastating fire that ripped through the top floor of the house in Crest Park Parade.</p><p>A 23-year-old former Bungendore resident has been awarded a $40000 scholarship to study nursing.</p><p>Sara Farnbach said she never planned to go to university, but now she's contemplating a postgraduate diploma.</p><p>February 18, 2005 Mayor of Queanbeyan Frank Pangallo fears the city may receive restrictions to water supplies which could curtail the future expansion of residential areas in the Queanbeyan local government area. This follows a warning by ACT Chief Minister Jon Stanhope that the financial costs of the construction of a new dam must be partly borne by Queanbeyan.</p><p>The Jerrabomberra Touch Association (JTA) is celebrating after being selected to host the 2005 Southern Suns Regional Tournament in November. More than 700 participants and officials are expected to converge on Queanbeyan for the weekend- long competition.</p><p>February 18, 1994 Five-year-old Alice Leigh, of Queanbeyan, can get about more comfortably, thanks to the efforts of Queanbeyan Blue Light Disco committee and the Queanbeyan Special Needs Group. Her father, Rob, said he owed a debt of gratitude to the two organisations for their efforts in helping to secure a special stroller for Alice, who suffers from cerebral palsy.</p><p>Brothers from Queanbeyan have won national sailing titles. They are Craig and Brent Davidson, who won a unique double at the national sailing titles held in Lake Macquarie, NSW. Both Craig and Trent won top titles sailing Spiral Class Dinghies, which are single-hull one- person boats.</p><p>February 19, 1990 Queanbeyan policemen, Senior Constable John Bernardi and Constable Michael Giles, have helped to raise $1000 for the ACT Guide Dogs Association by pretending to be escaped prisoners. The two police officers took part in Jail Break Ninety which was staged by Queanbeyan and Federal Police at the weekend.</p><p>February 18, 1980 Queanbeyan firemen were kept busy at the weekend fighting five fires in the city and district, ranging from a forest fire to the burning out of the Kentucky Fried Chicken store in Monaro Street. The Kentucky Fried food outlet in Monaro Street was extensively damaged by fire early on Sunday morning.</p><p>The teachers at Queanbeyan High School are continuing to refuse to teach students in oversize classes. The teachers are campaigning for smaller classes and increased lesson preparation time.</p><p>Queanbeyan professional cyclist Anthony O'Connor, has been chosen to represent NSW in the cadet pursuit team at the Australian championships.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">12031279</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">QUEANA2009</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:54PJ-J6N1-DXHW-F14D-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">390730</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">1901-11-11</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="503"/><publicationInfo><copyright>Copyright 2009 Fairfax Media Publications Pty. urn:contentItem:49N9-W3S0-01S8-G3K0-00000-00<published>1992-10-02T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>STRONG M</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Fires rage in California SACRAMENTO: Seven hundred firefighters yesterday battled to control a fast-spreading forest fire that has destroyed 3700ha of Californian forest and 40 buildings, officials said. The fire, raging in scenic, rugged forest east of the state capital of Sacramento, forced the evacuation of at least 200 people who are being temporarily accommodated in local schoolhouses.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Somali hopes MOGADISHU: The United Nations, in a landmark agreement with warring Somali chiefs, has agreed to deploy 750 Canadian troops in northern Somalia to protect relief workers from marauding gunmen. Gaza riots TEL AVIV: Seventy people were wounded yesterday in violent clashes between militants of the Islamic Resistance Movement and Palestinians. The fighting broke out in the afternoon in Khan Yunis, where 200 IRM supporters gathered outside a house inhabited by a Palestinian family and threw petrol bombs at the building. Wage outcry MEXICO CITY: Hundreds of farm workers angry over low wages seized a union building yesterday in a bloody clash. Two people were injured in a bottle-throwing battle as about 300 sugar-cane harvesters seized the six-storey building of the National Campesinos (farm workers) Centre. Police did not intervene. Gunship raid JERUSALEM: Israeli helicopter gunships made two raids on pro-Iranian guerrilla posts in south Lebanon yesterday, destroying a post belonging to the Hizbollah group in the village of Ain Bouswar and a Hizbollah-held house east of the southern port city of Tyre. No injury reports were available.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4582-1CD0-0197-F0N8-00000-00<published>1996-09-05T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WHAT'S ON; Pg. 22</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>PETERS M</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">KEYWORD-HIT</p><p nitf:lede="true">RATTLESNAKES</p><p nitf:lede="true">Lloyd Cole & The Commotions (Polydor)</p><p nitf:lede="true">WHEN the debut album from Lloyd Cole & The Commotions first appeared</p><p nitf:lede="true">in 1984, most record buying teens were caught between the floss of the</p><p nitf:lede="true">New Romantics, pub rock and the posturing</p><p nitf:lede="true">of The Cure and The Psychedelic</p><p nitf:lede="true">Furs.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Lloyd Cole cut through the great divide.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>The sole Englishman in the</p><p>group, the Commotions were a serious bunch of Scots whose trademark was</p><p>subtle/jangly playing behind Cole's Dylanesque wordplay.</p><p>On the album's first single, Perfect Skin, Lloyd talked of a girl</p><p>who offered to take you downstairs ""to look at slides of her family</p><p>life", she had ""cheekbones like geometry/and eyes like silk/and had</p><p>been sexually enlightened by Cosmopolitan". Music to the ears of any</p><p>serious undergraduate in a black skivvy.</p><p>The troupe really hit cred paydirt with the second single and title</p><p>track, Rattlesnakes. Catchy and melodic, Cole once again wove a lyrical</p><p>web that had the listener aching for the chorus.</p><p>""She looks like Eva Marie Saint/in On The Waterfront/She reads</p><p>Simone De Beauvoir/in her American circumstance."</p><p>The song also had Lloyd's best ever lyric: ""love is all you</p><p>need/but love was your great disappointment."</p><p>Other highlights included Down On Mission Street, Four Flights Up,</p><p>Are You Ready To Be Heartbroken? and Forest Fire.</p><p>It was on this record that Cole peaked. The lyrics often spoke of</p><p>famous actors, writers, books and longing. The instrumentation rarely</p><p>rose above a hum. There was never any serious rockin' out on a Lloyd</p><p>Cole record.</p><p>When Rattlesnakes arrived, it was like a breath of fresh air.</p><p>Sadly, any albums released by the group after this debut paled, often</p><p>amounting to nothing more than shallow imitations of this, their</p><p>spirited debut.</p><p>MITCHELL PETERS</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4B46-HK40-01S8-G1JJ-00000-00<published>1993-01-03T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">PEOPLE who give blood at the mobile blood bank outside Cinema Maroochydore tomorrow will be given free tickets to Bram Stoker's Dracula. A MAN, 27, was treated at the Royal Brisbane Hospital after having his face slashed with a broken beer bottle at a Brisbane city nightclub on Friday night.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>The assault occurred during a fight in Lexington Queen about 11pm.</p><p>A MAN, 18, was accidentally shot in the head while hunting on a property about 40km south of Roma on Friday evening. The unnamed dead man was one of three in the shooting party. The man was shot after he moved into the line of fire.</p><p>A MAN armed with a sawn-off shotgun held up the Clayfield Day and Night Chemist, at Sandgate Road, about 9pm on Friday. Police say the man threatened staff and stole a quantity of drugs and money. The man was 170cm, of slim build, aged about 25, with a fair complexion.</p><p>A CHILD was taken to the Royal Children's Hospital after a house fire at Stafford yesterday morning. The Brisbane Fire Service said the single storey wooden duplex house was severely damaged in the fire, which started about 6.50am.</p><p>VOLUNTEER firefighters last night contained a forest fire that had been burning on Stradbroke Island for about two weeks. The fire was 4km south of and heading towards Dunwich, a police spokesman said. It was the most dangerous fire on the island for a couple of years.</p><p>THE Sunshine Coast has the fourth highest number of break and enters in the state, police figures reveal.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49BY-V850-015G-Y226-00000-00<published>2003-08-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 21</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FIJI</p><p nitf:lede="true">Four dead</p><p nitf:lede="true">SUVA: Four Chinese nationals were killed yesterday after a fight broke out at a fish export factory near Suva, police said. Fiji Television said a security guard arrived at Live Fish Fiji Export Ltd to discover the Chinese fighting. He phoned the police who arrived to find four bodies.</p><p>CANADA</p><p>Thousands flee</p><p>VANCOUVER: Thousands of people were forced to flee their homes in western Canada as a forest fire jumped containment lines and moved into the outskirts of Kelowna, British Columbia. CBC television reported that 1000 homes, and an estimated 5000 people, had been ordered evacuated yesterday from the southern outskirts of the city, about 300km east of Vancouver.</p><p>NZ</p><p>Quake hits Fiordland</p><p>WELLINGTON: A huge earthquake rocked southern New Zealand early yesterday, authorities said. It rattled houses and hotels but caused no injuries or major damage in the mountainous and sparsely populated region. The 7.1-magnitude quake struck the picturesque farming and tourism area of South Island's Fiordland.</p><p>MALI</p><p>Libya pays ransom</p><p>BAMAKO: Libya paid a $5 million ($8.47 million) ransom "on its own initiative" to the abductors of 14 European hostages who were released this week after having been held for months in the Sahara Desert, diplomats said yesterday. The money passed "neither through Malian nor German hands", the diplomat said after the freed hostages returned home safely on Wednesday to Germany, Switzerland and the Netherlands.</p><p>BRITAIN</p><p>Sex problems</p><p>LONDON: Lack of interest in sex, premature orgasm among men, inability to orgasm among women and anxiety about sexual performance are chronic problems in Britain, according to studies to be published in today's issue of the British Medical Journal. A survey of 1065 London women and 447 London men who consulted a doctor found that 40 per cent of the women were diagnosed with a sexual problem and the rate was 22 per cent among men.</p><p>CROATIA</p><p>Tanks surface</p><p>BATINA: The record drought shrinking the Danube River has revealed ships, tanks and other equipment from the battles of World War II. A tank and an armoured personnel carrier broke the surface downstream from Batina and further downstream, in Serbia, the rusty 60-year-old remnants of several warships, believed to be part of Germany's Black Sea Fleet, have begun protruding in recent days.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49K0-2260-01S8-G190-00000-00<published>1986-07-12T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>COSTELLO D</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Evangelists on bail KAJANG._ A court yesterday adjourned to next week the case of two New Zealand Christian missionaries charged with hurting a Malaysian Moslem's religious feelings by saying the Koran and Islam were untrue.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Bail was extended for Grant Terrence Nesdale, 28, of Hamilton, and Julian Mary Miessen, 27, of Christchurch. Palace honor for Geldof LONDON._ The Queen has broken with modern tradition to give Irish famine-aid hero Bob Geldof his honorary knighthood, a Buckingham Palace spokesman said. The singer has been invited to a Palace investiture on July 24. Hess cancer rumor BERLIN._ Rudolf Hess, once the deputy to Nazi dictator Adolf Hitler, apparently was suffering from stomach cancer but his life was not threatened, the Berliner Morgenpost newspaper reported yesterday. Beauty takes own life BUDAPEST._ Csilla Andrea Molnar, 17, crowned ""Miss Hungary 1985" last year in the country's first beauty contest since the war, committed suicide yesterday, the national radio reported. She had recently complained about rumors which said she was being showered with cash and presents. Germans may face gallows BONN._ At least 16 West Germans were being detained in South-East Asia on drugs charges and many could face the death penalty, the Foreign Ministry said yesterday. Activists start blaze WOENSDRECHT, Netherlands._ Anti-nuclear protesters started a forest fire yesterday in woods around the Woensdrecht airbase, earmarked to receive US Cruise missiles in 1988, police said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49KR-WPN0-01S8-C1VH-00000-00<published>1988-11-03T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>SALE PENNY</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Warning on fire danger for state By PENNY SALE TASMANIANS were warned yesterday to prepare for a summer of extreme fire danger.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"Yesterday the conditions were ripe for a major outbreak of forest fire," a spokesman for the Tasmania Fire Service said.</p><p>"If landowners do not heed warnings to clear their property of excess undergrowth and debris now, the real danger may lay ahead," he said.</p><p>He urged people to clear land now, in anticipation of a hot, dry and windy summer.</p><p>He said the amount of rain during the past few months had enabled undergrowth to flourish and with the onslaught of the summer heat, graziers would not be able to clear enough undergrowth in time for the really hot weather.</p><p>"We have certainly got the heaviest grass fuel bed that we have had since the early 1970s," the spokesman said.</p><p>Yesterday, Hobart reached the forecasted maximum of 32 degrees shortly after 3pm, while Launceston reached 26. The state's maximum was 33 degrees at St Helens.</p><p>The Coles Bay area is the first victim of this summer's hot, windy conditions, where fire has so far burnt 2,500 hectares.</p><p>The regional chief fire officer for Southern Tasmania, Mr John Gledhill, said yesterday he was concerned the fire could spread through Freycinet National Park where the fire was looming at the northern tip.</p><p>According to the Bureau of Meteorology, Hobart is in for another warm day today. The expected maximum is 24 degrees.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source Fugitive held TEMPE, Arizona._ One of the FBI's 10 most wanted fugitives, who escaped from a Michigan prison three years ago and also was sought on kidnap and rape charges, was back behind bars yesterday. Ronald Glyn Triplett, 37, was arrested without incident on Saturday evening and was held in Maricopa County Jail, said Herbert Hawkins, head of the FBI office in Phoenix. Police protest LIMA._ Striking Peruvian police dispersed yesterday after President Alan Garcia threatened to send in troops to evict them from barracks they had been occupying to press for higher pay. US cool on talks WASHINGTON._ The United States had not promised to participate in an international Middle East peace conference and would only proceed in that direction if Israel approved, the US Secretary of State, Mr Shultz, said yesterday. Setback for Kohl BONN._ Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrats have suffered serious losses to the liberal Free Democrats, junior partners in his centre-right coalition, in two State elections overshadowed by a Government failure to agree on Soviet arms proposals.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49N3-RNT0-01S8-C4K1-00000-00<published>1992-11-25T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Making a splash! Field Air's turbo-powered firefighter at Cambridge yesterday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Water bomber's target audience WITH the fire season approaching Tasmanian authorities turned out yesterday to watch a turbo-powered water bomber put through its paces at Cambridge airport.</p><p>The water bomber, owned by Victorian company Field Air, demonstrated its ability to drop 1500 litres of water onto fires.</p><p>With an airport close at hand the bomber can deliver 3600 litres an hour.</p><p>Field Air salesman Mr Ray Mackay said the advantage of the aircraft was that it could deliver water right on the site of the fire.</p><p>"The aircraft has a multi-drop fire door which enables the water drop to be changed depending on whether it is a grass or forest fire," Mr Mackay said.</p><p>But Tasmanian authorities were unconvinced yesterday.</p><p>The regional fire officer with the Tasmanian Fire Service, Mr John Gledhill, said fixed-wing aircraft had never been used successfully in Tasmania.</p><p>"They are constrained by having to fly back to an airport to get loaded up and back to the fire," Mr Gledhill said.</p><p>"It is probably more effective to use people on the ground." A senior fire protection officer with the Department of Parks, Wildlife and Heritage, Mr Tony Blanks, said tree canopies in Tasmanian bush were too high for water to be dropped effectively.</p><p>"Its application is also limited because of the lack of airstrips, but it could be useful with ground backup," Mr Blanks said.</p><p>A Forestry Commission spokesman, Mr Rod McNeil, said the plane could be afforded only if the cost was shared between several authorities.</p><p>"It would be very expensive to have it over here on a standby basis," Mr McNeil said.</p><p>Officials from Australian Pulp and Paper Mills and Australian Newsprint Mills Forest Management also attended.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>Field Air's turbo-powered firefighter at urn:contentItem:49N9-W3S0-01S8-G3KJ-00000-00<published>1992-10-02T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>STRONG M</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Fires rage in California SACRAMENTO: Seven hundred firefighters yesterday battled to control a fast-spreading forest fire that has destroyed 3700ha of Californian forest and 40 buildings, officials said. The fire, raging in scenic, rugged forest east of the state capital of Sacramento, forced the evacuation of at least 200 people who are being temporarily accommodated in local schoolhouses.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Peace bid PARIS: French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas will travel to Syria, Israel and Egypt at the weekend in an effort to promote Middle East peace negotiations, his office announced yesterday. Somali hopes MOGADISHU: The United Nations, in a landmark agreement with warring Somali chiefs, has agreed to deploy 750 Canadian troops in northern Somalia to protect relief workers from marauding gunmen. Gaza riots TEL AVIV: Seventy people were wounded yesterday in violent clashes between militants of the Islamic Resistance Movement and Palestinians. The fighting broke out in the afternoon in Khan Yunis, where 200 IRM supporters gathered outside a house inhabited by a Palestinian family and threw petrol bombs at the building. Wage outcry MEXICO CITY: Hundreds of farm workers angry over low wages seized a union building yesterday in a bloody clash. Two people were injured in a bottle-throwing battle as about 300 sugar-cane harvesters seized the six-storey building of the National Campesinos (farm workers) Centre. Police did not intervene. Border clash DOHA: Qatar yesterday decided to unilaterally end a 1965 border agreement with Saudi Arabia after its government said Saudi troops killed two soldiers and captured a third in an attack on a border post yesterday. Saudi Arabia said the incident was a clash between bedouin tribesmen which left two Qataris and one Saudi dead.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:49N0-YM70-01S8-C0K4-00000-00<published>1992-08-27T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Lela Garrigus and her dog, Muffin, survey the fire-ravaged ruins of her home at Red Mountain, California. The fire in the Shasta Forest is still burning.</p><p>Hundreds homeless in California blaze Los Angeles WEARY firefighters say they are hopeful they may at last have the upper hand on a blaze that has burned 28,300 hectares of Californian forest and left hundreds of people homeless.</p><p>The fire, in the Shasta Forest 65 kilometres north-east of Redding, is the worst forest fire in California since 1987.</p><p>It has wiped out two small towns, partially destroyed two others, and forced the evacuation of at least 7500 people.</p><p>At least 300 homes have been reduced to ashes, as have 260 other buildings, since the blaze started last Thursday.</p><p>Although the fire was 50 per cent contained by yesterday, it was still too early to celebrate, said a fire information officer.</p><p>Fire crews thought they had the blaze under control but it was fanned by unexpectedly high winds overnight and forced more evacuations.</p><p>In addition to property damaged, the blaze has also destroyed $US86 million ($A121.69 million) worth of standing commercial timber - enough to build 50,000 three-bedroom homes or to keep seven sawmills busy for a year, state officials said.</p><p>Elsewhere in California, a 3230-hectare fire was still burning in the Inyo National Forest south of Yosemite National Park, while other, smaller fires throughout the state were largely under control.</p><p>In Idaho, the worst fire ever in the Boise National Forest has charred 104,245 hectares by and is being battled by 2500 firefighters.</p><p>Only one home has been lost, but much forest and range is devastated.</p><p>Reuter</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>Lela Garrigus and her dog, Muffin, survey the fire-ravaged ruins ofher home614.84 FIRES urn:contentItem:49K0-22R0-01S8-G3M4-00000-00<published>1986-08-26T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>COSTELLO D</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">French blaze kills fireman MARSEILLES._ A fireman yesterday became the fourth victim of France's worst forest fire for several years, police said.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>The 20-year-old fireman died of suffocation when his rescue vehicle was surrounded by flames in the Bouches-du-Rhone region. Typhoon sweeps back TAIPEI._ Rogue typhoon Wayne, which killed 52 people and left 24 missing as it rampaged through Taiwan on Friday, yesterday made a U-turn over the Pacific and swept back to strike a glancing blow, authorities said. Drug mission intercepted NEW DELHI._ Indian authorities had seized 472 kg of heroin and 1041 kg of hashish as it was being smuggled from Pakistan on a truck, the Press Trust of India (PTI) said yesterday. The narcotics _ valued by sources at tens of millions of dollars _ were concealed in 260 bags of clay. Khomeini vows to fight on TEHRAN._ Iranian spiritual leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini said yesterday Iran must reject any truce in the Gulf war, fight until victory and ""finish" the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein. Israel may back sanctions TEL AVIV._ A senior Israeli official said yesterday he expected the Prime Minister, Mr Peres, to tell Cameroun's leaders during his visit to that country this week that Israel would support Western economic sanctions against South Africa. Reagan summit sought LUSAKA._ The Zambian President, Mr Kaunda, said yesterday he would ask President Reagan to meet the leaders of the black-governed nations bordering South Africa to develop a new policy toward the region.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49KJ-J5V0-01S8-80XW-00000-00<published>1988-10-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">CARAVANS (1978), Channel 7, noon: Entertaining version of James</p><p nitf:lede="true">Michener's contemporary desert epic. The search of the Middle</p><p nitf:lede="true">East for the daughter of a US senator results in a feud between</p><p nitf:lede="true">two tribes.</p><p>Stars Jennifer O'Neill.</p><p> AN AMERICAN WEREWOLF IN LONDON (1981), Channel 10, 8.30pm:</p><p>Unique horror movie which has a wonderful sense of humor. David Naughton is</p><p>a young American tourist who was attacked by a werewolf</p><p>while lost on the English moors during a full moon. He unwittingly</p><p>brings a trail of mayhem and murder to London.</p><p> WOMAN IN RED (1984), Channel 7, 8.30pm: Enjoyable comedy about</p><p>a happily married advertising executive (Gene Wilder) who becomes</p><p>infatuated with a stunning woman in a red dress (Kelly LeBrock).</p><p>He finds himself torn between the love he feels for his wife</p><p>and his infatuation with this mysterious woman.</p><p> MURPHY'S ROMANCE (1986), Channel 9, 8.33pm: Charming and easy-going</p><p>comedy about a young divorcee (Sally Field) who, along with</p><p>her 12-year-old son, decides to make a new start on an Arizona</p><p>horse ranch. Also stars James Garner.</p><p> FIRE (1977), Channel 9, 12.10am: Staid drama which looks at</p><p>the devastating effects of a forest fire which threatens the</p><p>life of a lumber-producing community. Stars Ernest Borgnine</p><p>and Vera Miles.</p><p> HANGED MAN (1974), Channel 9, 2.15am: Interesting idea which</p><p>suffers from a lack of imagination. Steve Forrest is a gunslinger</p><p>who miraculously survives his own execution and becomes an avenger</p><p>fighting for justice in the Old West.</p><p> THE ALIENS ARE COMING (1980), Channel 9, 3.40am: Slick science</p><p>fiction tale about extraterrestrial beings from a dying planet</p><p>secretly landing on earth and assuming the forms of human beings. Stars Tom</p><p>Mason and Melinda Fee.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier
