urn:contentItem:5J47-SRN1-JD67-11JS-00000-00<published>2016-02-18T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline><author><person><nameText>Ainslee Dennis</nameText></person></author></nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE Commonwealth Bank building in Victoria Street, Taree is for sale.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Workmen have been modifying and beautifying the building in recent weeks under the watchful eye of Eddie Ryan of Century 21Taree.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Mr Ryan is now calling for expressions of interest from potential buyers and says the owner is hoping to realise between $2.5 million and $3 million.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The successful sale of the building could allow community access to the majestic Aboriginal-inspired mural by Australian artist, Byram Mansell. It currently stands behind locked glass doors.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The building is located between Spotlight and Aboriginal radio station, Ngarralinyi, and has not been occupied by the Commonwealth Bank since the late '90s.</p><p>It has been intermittently leased during that time and is now the only vacant premises on Victoria Street between Manning Street and Pulteney Street.</p><p>The building is a dominant feature in the section of the central business district that is transforming as Tidy Up Taree and Greater Taree City Council collaborate on the 'Civic heART' project and the implementation of its Vibrant Spaces policy.</p><p>The street now features sculptures, garden beds and new seating structures that encourage people to stop and experience the street and enjoy the increasing number of art installations.</p><p>People who walk Victoria Street see giant goanna footprints that cover parts of the pavement and the entrance to the recently refurbished Centerpoint Arcade now features four Manning Valley tallowwood logs carved to reveal goannas by acclaimed Aboriginal artist, Russell Saunders; when they wander into the arcade they can admire another sculpture and water feature by the same artist that is a celebration of the original inhabitants of the Manning Valley, the people of the Biripi nation.</p><p>Stepping back on to Victoria Street, next to the Commonwealth Bank building and in front of the Aboriginal radio station, Ngarralinyi, is a Rick Reynolds wood sculpture of a giant goanna and his metal sculpture, Balancing Act, stands in front of the Centrelink office. The Three Brothers sculpture by Malcolm Wallace and Renae Dixon is installed near the Commonwealth Bank building and the street also features a giant abacus by Lee Black at the front of accounting firm, GPB Partners.</p><p>The large Mansell mural is visible from the street but it is from a distance and the glass wall obscures the colours and details.</p><p>According to a leaflet produced by the Commonwealth Bank, the mural was commissioned in 1956 and "with some of the coloured clays dug in the hills of Taree, Mr Mansell created a large ceramic mural depicting an Aboriginal legend of Taree."</p><p>Mr Ryan says the mural is "a beautiful feature of the building" and believes "the building would be a great investment for buyers looking to secure a three level building that features a basement area and an undercover carpark in the heart of Taree."</p><p>For further information about the property contact Mr Ryan at Century 21 in Taree on 6552 5500.</p><p>IN 1956 the Commonwealth Bank commissioned Australian artist, Byram Mansell to design a mural for its new premises in Victoria Street, Taree</p><p>According to a commemorative leaflet produced by the Commonwealth Bank, the mural interprets an "Australian Aboriginal legend of Taree, Bilinga and The Fig Tree'.</p><p>This is the story:</p><p>"In the dreamtime when the mists of time rolled away, legend tells of a wise man who lived with a wandering tribe of Aboriginals, so far back that the name has long been forgotten through the ages.</p><p>Nuruna was the name of the warrior, who will always be remembered. Nuruna was a deep thinker and a clever man, as you will hear.</p><p>He was a friend of all the animals that roamed throughout the land, and the birds that made their home in the high gum trees and on the ground.</p><p>He was a friend of all the animals that roamed throughout the land, and the birds that made their homes in the high gum trees and on the ground.</p><p>Nuruna wandered over the vast mountains and hills and along the many deep valleys. He would stop to hear the water cascading over the stones, for it was a sweet sound. Nuruna knew the language of the brook. Along the banks of the stream grew many strange and beautiful flowers, for no other country but Australia has such flora. The rainbow colours of the flowers delighted Nuruna very much. He and his tribe were happy in these surroundings.</p><p>The birds in those far off days were all drab and not like they are now. The only sound they could make was a faint chirp. Nuruna thought long and deeply about all these things.</p><p>One day when resting on the bank of the stream after a long journey, for the day had been very hot, Nuruna's attention was drawn to Allinga, the sun, shining through the trees, casting his flickering light on the edge of a deep cave.</p><p>The colours on the side of the cave were made more beautiful to look upon by these darting shafts of light.</p><p>Such earth colours are used by Aboriginals to paint their bodies when they hold their corroborees, to dance and imitate the actions and customs of the animals and birds they know so well.</p><p>After much meditation Nuruna decided he would paint the birds in these gay colours just like the flowers that grew upon the land.</p><p>So, one by one, as the birds came to drink of the cool waters Nuruna painted them in different colours, and as they flew away in their gay splendour the birds started to sing a song of joy; each in his own tune and all have to do so even to this very day!</p><p>The last of the birds to come and drink were painted with a white clay; this the Aboriginals call the "milk of mother earth'. When this was done the birds flew into the sky rejoicing with their song.</p><p>Now, Peralla the turkey lived in the deep forest and never mingled with the other birds. Hearing their strange song and looking up he saw their bright colours as they flew overhead.</p><p>Discovering what had happened, Peralla, who was a surly fellow, became very jealous. There and then he vowed a vengeance. He became so angry he rushed off to the great smouldering oak; and, as you know, this strange tree of fire was forever burning in the Dreamtime and from this tree the Aboriginals of old lit their firesticks to start their camp fires, long before they knew how to make fire themselves.</p><p>The turkey in those days was very strong and was able to push over the smouldering oak; which he did. The fire, now released from the fallen tree, leaped among the dry grass and leaves, and very soon the whole forest was ablaze. Never was there such a fire before, not has there been one since. Peralla the wicked turkey was determined to burn everything up. The great billowing flames and smoke spread over the land.</p><p>Bilinga, the magpie, flying through the flames of the forest fire became partly black, and has remained so. The great ordeal of the fire had robbed them of their song. On, on they flew towards the coast, being guided by a big winding river that still flows to this very day and is known as the Manning.</p><p>As darkness descended over the land and the fire was left far behind, Bilinga and his mate took shelter and rested after their long flight in a tree with large leaves. As the dawn broke over the hills they discovered the strange tree bore many figs. Bilinga's mate gave him some of the fruit to eat which restored his song. To this day the magpie can be heard singing his delightful notes as the great sun Allinga gives the morning light over our great land.</p><p>This pleasant place by the river where Bilinga the magpie was given the fruit that restored his song so long ago was named by the Aboriginals Taree, the "Home of the Fig".</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5G80-78N1-DYTG-2061-00000-00<published>2015-06-20T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>A</positionSection><positionSequence>Pg. F017</positionSequence></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline><author><person><nameText>The Canberra Times</nameText></person></author></nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Hush Hush Laura Lippman Faber & Faber, $29.99 This is the 12th novel in Lippman's series about Tess Monaghan, Baltimore reporter turned private investigator. The story features Melisandre, who shares the imperious manner and sexualised charm of her Game of Thrones namesake. Ten years ago Melisandre killed her baby daughter but fled the country after escaping conviction. Returning 10 years later, she wants to be reunited with her surviving two daughters, and Tess is drawn into the situation by her friend Tyner, who is Melisandre's lawyer.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Despite the mysteries that drive the plot, the book's real focus is the process of parenting. What drove Melisandre to kill her baby? Why does she want her surviving teenage daughters back now, and what lessons does her story have for Tess' own less-than-perfect parenting techniques? This is skilful, entertaining storytelling, from a very experienced hand.</p><p>Something Is Rotten Adam Sarafis Echo Publishing, $29.99 When the lovelorn, hamburger-munching Brent meets his doom mere seconds after hopefully emailing the manuscript of his novel off to a publisher, his friend Jade ropes in a third party to help get to the bottom of Brent's strange death. The helper is one Sam Hallberg, a man with big problems of his own. In the action-packed first dozen or so pages it's made clear that Brent's death was murder and that dirty deals are being done in very high places.</p><p>Adam Sarafis is the pseudonym of a collaboration between two New Zealand authors, fiction writer Linda Olsson and screenwriter and playwright Thomas Sainsbury, and one noticeable result of this male-female collaboration is a cast of convincing characters of both sexes. Journalist Liz and walk-on murder victim Brent in particular are two of the most vivid and believable characters I've seen in contemporary thrillers and crime fiction.</p><p>The Painted Sky Alice Campion Bantam, $32.99 When hip young Sydney raver Nina Larkin inherits an outback property called Wandalla and heads north-west to check it out, she discovers a great deal more than she bargained for, including old friends, strange enemies, secretive lawyers and a family mystery.</p><p>It also becomes a voyage of self-discovery. Alice Campion is the pen-name of a five-author team of women from a Sydney book club who set themselves the challenge of writing a 21st-century answer to The Thorn Birds. The result is a highly entertaining and page- turning hybrid, part rural romance and part family saga.</p><p>Although it's not a parody, it shows a high degree of self-awareness and humour. At the end, as well as the inevitable assortment of recipes for various foods mentioned in the story - classic CWA-type fare including lamingtons, pavlova, and sausage rolls -- there's an intriguing interview describing the collaborative process.</p><p>Troll Mountain Matthew Reilly Macmillan, $24.99 Raf of the Northmen tribe is about to lose his beloved sister to the disease that is ravaging his people. Learning that a cure may be found in the haunts of the Troll King on Troll Mountain, Raf sets off on the dangerous quest through the Badlands to steal the elixir and save his sister and his tribe, a quest strewn with helpers, opponents, and tests of cleverness and strength.</p><p>The genre for which Reilly is best known, the action thriller, is one that often sacrifices style to content, and his departure into the fantasy genre with Troll Mountain hasn't changed that basic dynamic. Although Reilly says it was inspired by listening to Greig's In the Hall of the Mountain King, and although the influences of Tolkien, George R.R. Martin, and J.K. Rowling are obvious, this book is really just an action thriller in disguise, with lots of conflict and heroics but little in the way of nuance or subtlety.</p><p>Letters to My Grandchildren David Suzuki NewSouth Books, $29.99 Shockingly, in this series of essays addressed to his grandchildren, Suzuki uses the "C" word - capitalism, which is usually draped in euphemistic language such as "the marketplace" now. In deliberately simple language, Suzuki covers a range of topics; the Great Depression, its forgotten lessons, the post-war birth of relentless consumerism and planned obsolescence; the current state of the world reeling from being constantly used as a resource, citing "fracking" as one of the great insanities of the age; ageing, the cult of youth, atheism and the inevitability of death. In this letter he invokes the tale of the South American hummingbird that carries drops of water to a forest fire one at a time much to the amusement of its fellow creatures, responding to their laughter with the words "I'm doing the best I can". More than the marketplace wolves can say.</p><p>After Perfect Christina McDowell Bantam, $34.99 The film The Wolf of Wall Street is one of those Fieldingesque tales featuring picaresque rogues that, to many, is emblematic of the crass excess of the 1990s. Intended as a cautionary tale. To McDowell, daughter of Tom Prousalis (a business associate of the real wolf, Jordan Belfort, who went to jail for fraud), the film romanticised the con-men it depicted. This is the tale from the daughter's point of view. No loveable rogues, just duplicitous cheats who cause tremendous damage to their families and society. McDowell, who changed her name, charts her family's fall from grace (the sale of the family mansion and the holiday house on Nantucket Island, divorce), and her own from privilege to working in seedy bars, homelessness, bit acting, drink and drugs. It's a record of the personal cost of those years, but also documents her forgiveness of her father and her gritty determination to go forward.</p><p>Good Muslim Boy Osamah Sami Hardie Grant, $32.95 There are times in this memoir that are reminiscent of migrant tales such as They're a Weird Mob, when we see our culture, rituals and colloquialisms through an uncomprehending outsider's eyes.</p><p>The unfortunately named Osamah, a writer, actor and film-maker (Ali's Wedding, to be released next year), weaves comedy and family tragedy together. In 2013 he went to Iran with his father, a leading Melbourne Shiite cleric, who suddenly died of a heart attack. One of the two stories running through the book is about his struggle to get the body back to Australia before his visa expires. The other describes his time growing up in Iran during the Iran/Iraq war, before arriving in Australia as refugees on humanitarian visas, landing in the northern suburbs of Melbourne, becoming a supporter of the Essendon Bombers! (his father's ironic choice), negotiating the language and much more. A funny, perceptive, distinctive voice.</p><p>Darjeeling Jeff Koehler Bloomsbury, $49.99 If market price is anything to go by Darjeeling is the champagne of teas, Koehler maintains in this readable history of the plant. It's an embracing study of a small leaf that goes back 2500 years to China, then on to key turning-points such as the establishment of the East India Company in 1600 and the importation of tea to Europe, especially England. At first it was the drink aristocrats, then the wealthy, then the whole country. And, all the time, Darjeeling (from the cool north of India), was the most expensive, the choice of connoisseurs. Koehler knows his brew and writes about it with great enthusiasm. The big question is will the tea - which requires intensely personalised harvesting - survive the pace of economic change, a growing Indian middle class disinclined to be paid a pittance for plucking tea, and political unrest? Or, will it all end in teas?</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49M1-RXF0-01S8-C2S9-00000-00<published>1989-09-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>BREEN FIONA</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Taste Commotions' classics 0 1984-1989 Lloyd Cole & The Commotions Polygram 0 IT seems surprising, but here it is - a comprehensive anthology of Lloyd Cole and The Commotions' last five years.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The surprise is due to the fact that during those five years they released three very fine albums, so it seems a little bewildering that there was any need to to highlight their somewhat brief career.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Since the release of their first single, Perfect Skin, in 1984, The Commotions have maintained a delicious buoyancy while others around them have drowned in a sea of mediocrity.</p><p>These have been desperate times in the UK, with so much depending on style, attitude and fashion. But The Commotions have stemmed the tide of artistic flippancy with their adaptation of a fairly basic formula that combines the lyrical intensity of Cole with a sort of country and westernish Velvet Underground.</p><p>At least, that's the first description given of the band by critic Julie Burchill.</p><p>But there may be some who have not experienced the band beyond the first couple of singles. So in that respect this compilation has some method in it's madness.</p><p>From the debut album comes the title track, Rattlesnakes, Perfect in, Forest Fire, Are You Ready to be Heartbroken? and You Will Never be no Good, which was originally only included on the CD release.</p><p>Easy Pieces is represented by Cut Me Down, Brand New Friend, Lost Weekend, Perfect Blue and that elusive CD extra, Her Last Fling.</p><p>Finally, 1987's runnaway classic, Mainstream, yields the remaining four, My Bag, From The Hip, Jennifer She Said and Mr Malcontent.</p><p>It's a splendid package for the uninitiated. But if you truly value this band you should investigate all three albums, particularly the CD issue because of those extra tracks.</p><p>Maybe this compilation should have been a "best of" triple album package. After all, what an awesome task it must have been selecting the nuggets for this retrospective release.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">HOBARTMERCURYLTD</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:49M1-RXF0-01S8-C2S9-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">244810</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2019-02-02</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="327"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>Hobart Mercury</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1989 Nationwide News Pty Limited</copyright><publicationDate day="06" month="09" year="1989"><dateText>September 6, 1989 Wednesday</dateText></publicationDate><classification classificationScheme="publicationtype"><classificationItem><className>Newspapers</className></classificationItem></classification></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem classificationScheme="lang.english"><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="subject"><classificationItem score="51"><classCode>STX001009</classCode><className>FOREST FIRES</className></classificationItem></classification><classification classificationScheme="industry"><classificationItem score="90"><classCode>STX001070</classCode><className>RECORD RELEASES</className></classificationItem></classification><classification classificationScheme="country"><classificationItem score="71"><classCode>GC329</classCode><className>UNITED KINGDOM</className></classificationItem></classification></classificationGroup></metadata></articleDoc></content></entry>

urn:contentItem:49KD-6HF0-01S8-G3K2-00000-00<published>1987-08-09T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>AAPINTNEWS</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">LONDON._ An airliner carrying hundreds of passengers had to make two emergency landings within hours at Heathrow yesterday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Both times the Trans World Airlines Tri-Star arrived back safely with one of its three engines shut down and fire and rescue services standing by.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>BONN._ The West German Government might send a small navy fleet to the North Atlantic or the Mediterranean to free US ships for Persian Gulf duty, a defence spokesman said.</p><p>KOBLENZ._ A West German schoolteacher, accused of telling pupils that Nazi concentration camps were a fabrication, received a nine-month suspended sentence for inciting racial hatred and insulting behavior.</p><p>LONDON._ Dutch police said they had broken up one of Amsterdam's most important hard drug rings after netting a record $7.8 million heroin haul in the city.</p><p>LONDON._ A pigeon fancier serving a three-year sentence for grievous bodily harm has ended a 24-hour rooftop protest against the extermination of hundreds of pigeons at Strangeways Prison, Manchester.</p><p>STOCKHOLM._ The prosecutor probing accusations that Swedish arms maker Bofors smuggled millions of dollars worth of weapons to Iran and other blacklisted countries asked yesterday for more time to complete his investigations.</p><p>MOSCOW._ Two people died and five were injured when the roof of the Kemerovo air terminal in western Siberia partly collapsed, the construction magazine Stroytelnaya Gazeta reported.</p><p>GENEVA._ AIDS cases reported around the world rose by 924 in one week to a total of 56,320 cases in 121 countries, the World Health Organisation said.</p><p>WARSAW._ A Polish military court jailed a conscript for two years for refusing to take the military oath, which pledges Poland's allegiance to the Soviet Union.</p><p>CAPE TOWN._ The South African Government named 1169 people detained without trial under emergency rules declared 14 months ago to curb black unrest.</p><p>HONG KONG._ Twenty-three people have been arrested or charged in connection with a forest fire which ravaged north-eastern China in May, the New China News Agency said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49NV-BJS0-01S8-C30P-00000-00<published>1995-07-01T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>AAP</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Police deny murdering 17 MEXICAN officials denied charges yesterday that police murdered 17 peasants in cold blood, but relatives of the dead insisted it was a deliberate massacre. A day after the peasants were shot dead in a clash with state police, angry villagers called for justice. But the government rushed to defend itself from murder accusations, saying police had merely defended themselves from attack.</p><p>South Korea retaliates SOUTH Korea announced yesterday it was suspending deliveries of emergency rice to the communist North because a South Korean ship had been forced to raise a Northern flag when in port. A Unification Ministry spokesman said Seoul was not happy with an apology for the incident sent by a North Korean trade company and would therefore suspend further shipments pending a formal apology from North Korean authorities.</p><p>Alleged forest arsonists held TURKISH Cypriot police yesterday detained six people, including three foreigners, suspected of starting a huge forest fire in the north of the island, TAK news agency said. The foreigners were attacked by a group of 150 people while being taken to court in the Mediterranean holiday town of Kyrenia, the TurkishCypriot agency said. TAK said the three, whose nationalities it did not disclose, were remanded in custody for three days. The agency did not mention the fate of the other three suspects. The blaze began on Tuesday near the northern village of Malatya.</p><p>Israel may free prisoners ISRAEL has signalled it may agree to release hundreds of Palestinian prisoners as part of last-minute efforts to meet today's deadline for agreement on a troop pullout from the West Bank. Palestine Liberation Organisation leader Yasser Arafat accused Israel yesterday of using the detainees as hostages to force the Palestinians to make fresh concessions before the deadline. Yesterday, thousands of prisoners went into the 13th day of a hunger strike.</p><p>11 agree on dumping moratorium ELEVEN European countries agreed in Brussels yesterday to a moratorium on dumping offshore oil rigs at sea, but the two key players, Norway and Britain, refused to go along. A four-day meeting of the OSPAR Commission, a multilateral group formed to protect the North Sea, ended with 11 of 13 member countries agreeing to a temporary ban on dumping that would come into force on August 4. Britain and Norway, the only countries involved with large deep-sea oil rigs, opposed the move.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4GJT-W1T0-015G-Y4GG-00000-00<published>2005-07-07T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 20</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">INDIA</p><p nitf:lede="true">Security upgrade</p><p nitf:lede="true">AYODHYA: Authorities tightened security at religious monuments across India yesterday to prevent sectarian clashes. The move comes a day after terrorists attacked a Hindu shrine at the heart of a decades-old conflict between majority Hindus and minority Muslims. The six assailants were killed in the attack and three security guards wounded. One of the attackers blew himself up in a jeep, tearing a hole in iron railings surrounding the shrine in Ayodhya and allowing the five other attackers to enter the complex where they died in a gunfight, police said. Hindu nationalists blamed the attack on Pakistan-backed Muslim militants.</p><p>PNG</p><p>PM in spotlight</p><p>PORT MORESBY: Prime Minister Michael Somare is under investigation for possible breaches of Papua New Guinea's Leadership Code after he put his son and his business adviser on the boards of state corporations. Sir Michael's son Sana was appointed to the board of PNG Power last month. The Prime Minister, pictured, also gave his business adviser Glen Blake a board position with Independent Public Business Corporation. Chief Ombudsman Ila Geno said his commission would conduct preliminary investigations into the row before taking a position.</p><p>PHILIPPINES</p><p>Husband off to US</p><p>MANILA: President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo's corruption-tainted husband left the Philippines yesterday for self-imposed exile in the US. The move is part of the embattled leader's efforts to distance herself from political scandals that threaten her Government. Jose Miguel "Mike" Arroyo, a lawyer who has been accused of influence-peddling and receiving kickbacks from illegal gambling, flew to Hong Kong. From there he will continue to his final destination in the US.</p><p>THAILAND</p><p>Officer beheaded</p><p>BANGKOK: A policeman was beheaded yesterday in troubled southern Thailand, the first member of the security forces to be decapitated in a string of such brutal attacks in the past month, police said. The body of 44-year-old Sergeant Samphan Onyala, who was on duty but plainclothed, was found in Yarang district of Pattani province, part of Thailand's deep south that has endured 18 months of deadly unrest. His body was found close to his motorcycle while authorities were still searching for the head, witnesses said.</p><p>FRANCE</p><p>Tourists flee fire</p><p>PARIS: About 5000 people, many of them tourists, were evacuated from six camping grounds on the French Riviera yesterday as an intense forest fire driven by high winds advanced on their tents and caravans. The fire apparently started in three locations around the village of Puget sur Argens and was raging through dry woodland, emergency services said. More than 400 firefighters, backed by dozens of vehicles and 11 waterbombing aircraft, were battling the flames, trying to stop them before they spread to about 1500 homes in the forested area.</p><p>UK</p><p>In a lather over nits</p><p>LONDON: Communal combs and hairbrushes have been removed from bathrooms in the British House of Commons after concerns that they could spread nits or infectious diseases such as HIV or hepatitis, it emerged yesterday. But MPs were reassured there had been no recorded cases of infestations or illnesses being spread in the parliamentary house, and the measure was being taken only to bring the Commons in line with modern health, safety and hygiene standards.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49M8-42N0-01S8-C015-00000-00<published>1990-12-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Summer hits and a city swelters SOUTHERN Tasmania sweltered yesterday when temperatures soared above 36 for the first time since January last year.</p><p nitf:lede="true">At 11am, the temperature had already reached 26 and by 2.38pm, Hobart had recorded the maximum temperature in the State of 36.1 .</p><p>Yesterday was the first day of total fire ban for the southern region for this season.</p><p>However, the only fire in the southern region which was causing concern was at the Australian Newsprint Mills concession area at Jungle Creek, about 14 kilometres west of Ouse. About 40 hectares had been burnt.</p><p>Yesterday was the warmest December day in Hobart since 1983 when a temperature of 36.8 was reached.</p><p>The warmest December day recorded was in 1897 - a scalding 40.7 .</p><p>While Launceston reached a warm 29 , Burnie and Devonport reached only 23 .</p><p>The average temperature for December is 20.2 .</p><p>The district fire officer for the East Coast, Mr David Downham, said fire permits were necessary for the 002 telephone area, as well as in the municipalities of Fingal, Flinders, Portland and King Island.</p><p>Mr Downham said yesterday that the forest fire danger rating was extreme.</p><p>"What we really have to rely on is the general public to be fire conscious and to take all precautions necessary to make sure their property is free of fire hazards," he said.</p><p>That could be done by mowing, picking up litter, burning off or grazing the areas around houses.</p><p>Mr Downham said there were good winter rains in most of the southern region and good average spring rains until about six or seven weeks ago, producing lush undergrowth which had dried out quickly.</p><p>Today, it is expected to reach a mild 23 in Hobart.</p><p>Picture: TONY PALMER</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>1) Santa attire is not exactly appropriate for summer and inyesterday's heat the fountain in Launceston's Quadrant Mall providedrelief. 2) Ah, that's better . . . Santa Claus resorted to a bucket ofwater to keep his cool in Hobart's Cat and Fiddle Arcade yesterday asthe city sweltered.394.2681) 6672/14 2) urn:contentItem:49M5-HS60-01S8-C0GD-00000-00<published>1990-07-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>AAP</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">IN BRIEF</p><p nitf:lede="true">Threat to species A RAPIDLY spreading forest fire is ravaging an important nature reserve in west-central Brazil, threatening to wipe out several endangered species, officials said yesterday. The fire began yesterday in the Sierra de Canastra national park near Belo Horizonte, capital of Minas Gerais state, spreading quickly in all directions because of a persistent drought, the fire department said. One-seventh of the park's 72,000 hectares already has been destroyed. Scientists are worried the fire may kill the region's few remaining ostriches and tamanduas (an arboreal anteater).</p><p>Poll boycott FIJI'S deposed coalition has declared it will boycott elections planned to be held under a yet-to-be adopted constitution designed to give indigenous Fijians political dominance over ethnic Indians. Senior coalition member Navin Maharaj said the unanimous decision was made by about 200 delegates at the National Federation Party-Labour Party meeting in Nadi at the weekend.</p><p>Step down plea AS rebel troops were reported to be fighting in suburbs of the Liberian capital Monrovia, government ministers taking part in abortive peace talks in neighbouring Sierra Leone called on President Samuel Doe to step down in the interests of peace. A delegation of ministers said a statement had been conveyed to President Doe and the president was "aware" of it, but "there has been no reaction as yet".</p><p>Embassy worry SPAIN'S ambassador in Havana told Cuban officials yesterday his government was very concerned about its embassy after nine unidentified Cubans broke in despite a heavy police guard, diplomatic sources said.</p><p>The sources, who asked not to be identified, said Mr Arturo Serrano de Haro told Cuban Foreign Ministry officials any incidents at the embassy, where nine Cuban asylum-seekers already were sheltering, could harm already strained relations between the two countries.</p><p>Cinema explosion AT least 11 people died and 18 were injured when a powerful bomb exploded in a crowded cinema in southern India yesterday, the Press Trust of India said. It was not immediately known who was responsible for the blast in the small theatre in Karnataka state's Bidar township, a police official was quoted as saying.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4B3B-X770-0197-V15F-00000-00<published>1993-12-10T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Fickle weather sparks fire fear An abundance of grass has left many part of the state open to bush fire this year . . . The Fire Permit Period was introduced in the Southern Region on November 17 and in the 003 area and King Island on December 3.</p><p nitf:lede="true">TASMANIA'S fickle weather pattern is evident again this year.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The East Coast and Southern Midlands had a dry winter while the North-East, North and North-West have an abundance of grass. Bush areas have dried out rapidly because of the lack of sub-soil moisture in the South-East and up the East Coast as far as Scamander.</p><p>The Fire Permit Period was introduced in the Southern Region on November 17 and in the 003 area and King Island on December 3.</p><p>The introduction of a Fire Permit Period should not mean that property owners cease burning. Permits can be obtained and brigades are then aware of the location of fires and this avoids the unnecessary checking of fires reported by the public.</p><p>The accumulation of timber harvesting residue is a major concern.</p><p>The practice of selective harvesting has created large areas where are residues required for firewood or where regeneration has occurred without the logging slash having been removed. It should be noted that fires burning in or burning into one of these areas at a Forest Fire Danger Rating of Moderate 10, would be almost impossible to control due to the heavy fuel loading.</p><p>Property owners should arrange with contractors to at least establish a fire break around the perimeterbefore logging an area. Trees are a valuable asset and it is the property owner's responsibility to take the appropriate protective measures.</p><p>The old practice of ploughing fire breaks in grassland or around cereal crops has almost ceased but there is an obvious reason to establish a fire break in a logged or regenerated area.</p><p>Autumn fuel reduction burning has never been popular with graziers simply because they wish to retain the dry vegetation for winter stock feed, however the autumn weather is much more stable than that of spring and burning at that time is a safer operation.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>An abundance of grass has left many part of the state open to bush fithis year614.849NO NEG</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:48WY-J9S0-015G-Y29P-00000-00<published>2003-06-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 14</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">JAPAN</p><p nitf:lede="true">Missile shield</p><p nitf:lede="true">TOKYO: Japan plans to deploy advanced interceptor missiles to beef up its defence system amid fears North Korea has up to 170 medium-range missile units targeting the country. The Yomiuri Shimbun newspaper said yesterday the Security Council of Japan and the Cabinet will adopt a plan to allocate funds for two types of missile systems -- Standard Missile-3 (SM-3) and Patriot Advanced Capability-3 (PAC-3) -- next month .</p><p nitf:lede="true">FRANCE</p><p nitf:lede="true">Bove in prison</p><p nitf:lede="true">MONTPELLIER: The French anti-globalisation hero, Jose Bove, pictured, was arrested yesterday to start a 10-month prison term for the destruction of a field of genetically-modified crops. Bove, 49, was whisked away by helicopter from his farm at Millau in southern France to the Villeneuve-les-Maguelone prison, police said.</p><p>NIGERIA</p><p>Church warning</p><p>LAGOS: The Church of Nigeria, the world's largest Anglican congregation, warned that it will break ranks with any Anglican community that condones homosexuality, its head, Archbishop Peter Jasper Akinola, said yesterday. The Nigerian church, with 17 million members, said earlier this month it had severed ties with the diocese of New Westminster in British Columbia, Canada, for authorising same-sex marriages. In another development, more than 100 Nigerian villagers were burned alive when a petrol pipeline exploded as they were looting fuel near the town of Ovim in the southeastern state of Abia, the head of the NigerianRed Cross said yesterday.</p><p>US</p><p>Forest fire</p><p>TUCSON: Firefighters cleared bush around a major astronomical observatory in the western US state of Arizona to save it from the largest of several bushfires that have raged out of control. The fires already have consumed thousands of hectares of old-growth forest and destroyed hundreds of homes. The 2630ha Aspen fire burned out of control for the fifth day yesterday.</p><p>BURMA</p><p>Red Cross bid</p><p>RANGOON: A Red Cross delegation arrived in northern Myanmar yesterday to meet with detained supporters of pro-democracy leader Aung San Suu Kyi, pictured, who are being held in a crackdown that has attracted worldwide condemnation. However, the military government has made it clear that the Red Cross team will not be allowed to meet Ms Suu Kyi, who is believed to be in the notorious Insein prison outside the capital Rangoon.</p><p>EGYPT</p><p>Circumcision ban</p><p>CAIRO: Delegates from 28 countries across the Middle East and Africa gathered in Cairo yesterday to pledge their commitment to eradicating female circumcision. Between 120 and 130 million women, mainly in Africa and the Arab world, were circumcised, while two million girls annually underwent the procedure, which involved the removal of the clitoris.</p><p>IRAN</p><p>Protests over</p><p>TEHRAN: A top Iranian police official declared the nearly 10 days of anti-regime protest to be over, while the Islamic republic's chief prosecutor vowed those detained in the unrest would be severely punished. Tehran's police chief Morteza Talai blamed the protests, which erupted at Tehran University on June 10 and spread to provincial cities, on "American government-financed foreign television stations" -- a reference to US-based satellite channels.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4586-MP60-0197-F2S4-00000-00<published>1998-08-07T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 12</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Olympic flame</p><p nitf:lede="true">ATHENS: A new forest fire broke out yesterday near ancient Olympia, home of the Olympic Games of antiquity, firemen said. Major resources were brought in to tackle the latest fire as officials feared that the ancient site might be damaged, a spokesman for the firefighting co-ordination centre said.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Guns silent</p><p nitf:lede="true">SRINAGAR: Artillery fell silent on India and Pakistan's disputed Kashmir border yesterday after a week of shelling which left more than 120 dead, Indian officials said. But they said tension remained high in the divided Himalayan region.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Leeson cancer</p><p>SINGAPORE: Nick Leeson, the imprisoned former securities trader whose futures dealing destroyed Britain's Barings bank, was in Changi Prison Hospital with colon cancer, the British High Commission said yesterday.</p><p>Ex-dictator dies</p><p>SOFIA: Bulgaria's former communist dictator Todor Zhivkov has died in a Sofia hospital at the age of 86, doctors said yesterday. Zhivkov ruled from 1954 until he was ousted in a bloodless coup by fellow party members in 1989. He was released from house arrest in September 1997 after becoming Eastern Europe's first communist leader to stand trial in 1991.</p><p>Seven dead</p><p>BERLIN: The bodies of seven people, including a boy of 13, were found in the ruins of a Berlin apartment block that collapsed after an apparent gas explosion, authorities said yesterday. The last body, that of a 68-year-old woman, was found in charred remains of the four-storey building's top floor last night. Rescue workers had earlier hoped to find the adolescent, identified only as Sven, alive after camera equipment detected signs of life under rubble 7m or 8m deep. Only the boy's dog was found alive.</p><p>Seoul floods</p><p>SEOUL: Another 60 people were feared dead or missing yesterday as record heavy overnight rains in South Korea unleashed landslides and fierce flooding in and around Seoul, officials said. The capital of about 12 million people was thrown into chaos, sending tens of thousands of citizens fleeing their flooded homes.</p><p>Early release</p><p>BELFAST: Britain could begin the early release of Northern Ireland's paramilitary prisoners by the end of the month, British officials said yesterday. Among paramilitaries the British Government deems eligible to be freed before the end of their sentences are members of the Irish Republican Army and the main Protestant groups.</p><p>Stance hailed</p><p>OTTAWA: An international symposium is recognising one of Canada's top medical ethicists for her declaration that circumcising baby boys is criminal assault. Dr Margaret Somerville of McGill University was scheduled to receive a human rights award yesterday at the fifth international symposium on sexual mutilations at Oxford University. The award recognises her courage for stating last year that male circumcision is as ethically wrong as female circumcision.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4BSV-H1Y0-0045-52JP-00000-00<published>2004-02-26T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>A;</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Report on 2001 firetoo slowTHE REPORT of the findings of the coronial inquiry into the bushfires of December 2001 (CT, February14, p5) left fundamental questions unanswered.Why was there not a total ban on lighting fires on December 24, when there was a ban in surrounding NSW? Were the resources that were made available adequate to contain a forest fire? Should the final size of this fire have been less than it was? Were the conclusions reached by the Emergency Services Bureau's internal review supported? Did the ESB's perceived success in dealing with this fire lead to a false sense of security in January 2003? But perhaps the most important question is why did we have to wait nearly 26 months for the report, during which time other sources of information were unavailable? Surely the time has come to follow the lead from aviation: after an air safety incident, the AustralianTransport Safety Board mounts a technical investigation,and its findings are made known promptly.Had there been a similar process after the December 2001 fires, we could have been better prepared for the big one in January 2003.TONY FEARNSIDE Fisher Let's have costsof VIP flightsTHE PRIME Minister's Chief of Staff, Arthur Sinodinos, is anxious to stress the savings that have been made in grounds maintenanceat the Lodge under the Howard Government (CT Letters, February 20). He points out that the present contract represents a saving of $34,000 a year on that in force in 1996, while savings over the last five years exceed $200,000.</p><p>Clearly, this has been a major achievement of the Howard Government.However, just to put these savings into perspective, there is little doubt that the full cost of running the RAAF VIP Squadron would exceed $200,000 a day, every day of the year. And $34,000 would not be too far removed from the real cost of every VIP flight between Sydney and Canberra by the non-resident Mr Howard.Given that Mr Sinodinos is clearly committed to full transparency in Government expenditure, he might like to reveal the real costs - the full costs - of all aspects of running the VIP Squadron, including the aircraft lease, maintenance contracts, RAAF staffing, operating expenditureand the Fairbairn lease.STEPHEN BROWNForrestSave us fromjunk mailFROM October 15 to January14 I carefully counted, weighed and recorded every item of "junk mail" in our letterbox each day. These the statistics.Number of days: 92; numberof delivery days: 38; total number of items: 262; averageweight per delivery: 189.4 grams, ranging from 55 grams to 1,030; average numberdelivered: 6.89, ranging from 3 to 12 items.The total weight of junk mail for the three months was 7kg and 197 grams.The reason why we haven't pasted up a "No Junk Mail" to date is that we believed advertising material was delivered by children wanting to earn a bit of pocket money. However, it seems that childrenhardly ever do this job. As far as we observed, all the stuff was bulk-delivered by adults.Most Canberra householders would probably agree that there's simply too much junk mail altogether. Would it be possible for the ACT Government to set a sensible limit to size and weight of advertising material?(Mrs) LEONORE HARDYScullin</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>AAP</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Serb power grab takes hold of all YugoslaviaBelgrade SERBIA yesterday moved to take control of all of Yugoslavia, grabbing remnants of federal power byc$taking over the near-defunct federal parliament.</p><p nitf:lede="true">A senior Western diplomat said the move effectively dissolved the eight-member federal presidency, which nominally controlled the Serb-dominated Yugoslav army.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The Serbian power grab was condemned by Macedonia - which like Croatia and Slovenia has declared its independence - and Bosnia-Hercegovina, where Croats and Muslims live in growing tensions with Serbs.</p><p>Meanwhile, the army has continued bombing the historic city of Dubrovnik, starting a raging forest fire, and has closed in on the Croatian capital of Zagreb.</p><p>Earlier this week, Croatian leaders said the attacks on the Adriatic coast represented a bid by Serbia to define a "Greater Serbia" that would include most of Yugoslavia but with the republic of Slovenia and some parts of Croatia eventually being allowed independence.</p><p>In Belgrade, representatives of the federal presidency from Montenegro and Serbia decided to take over the federal parliament.</p><p>The presidency's chairman, Mr Stipe Mesic, a Croat, was not at the meeting.</p><p>In a bizarre twist in the conflict yesterday, the Croatian President, Mr Franjo Tudjman, and the Serbian President, Mr Slobodan Milosevic, were believed to be heading to The Hague for peace talks sponsored by the European Community.</p><p>Serbs and Croats share a language and other cultural traits but have been rivals for centuries and were enemies during World War II when fascist Croats killed hundreds of thousands of Serbs, with the Serbs retaliating.</p><p>Zagreb television reported yesterday that Croatian forces had been pushed back to within 12 kilometres of the city after losing several villages to federal soldiers.</p><p>Serb rebels and federal troops were advancing north along a wide front in the Banija region, encountering little resistance from retreating Croat troops.</p><p>Federal navy warships have besieged Dubrovnik, an international tourist attraction that has been without water, power or phonelines for three days.</p><p>However, the federal forces have vowed not to destroy the fortified city, one of Europe's historic treasures.</p><p>When Croatia and Slovenia declared independence June 25, they agreed to a three-month delay in implementing their plans under an EC-brokered accord to give peace talks a chance to succeed.</p><p>More than 600 people have since been killed in fighting.</p><p>AP</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:49NV-BJS0-01S8-C2X1-00000-00<published>1995-06-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>AAP</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Wife put in freezer, court told A BRITISH prison officer clubbed his wife to death, dismembered her body and stored the parts in the family freezer, a court was told yesterday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Michael Allen, 44, allegedly hit his wife Myrtle over the head with a hammer as she slept. He hacked off her hair and tried to flush it down the toilet before cutting up her corpse, the Newcastle court heard.</p><p>Allen who worked in the hospital wing of a top security jail in Durham, northern England, denies murder but admits manslaughter and attempting to pervert justice by hiding the body.</p><p>Shoot-out with Mexican police FOURTEEN people were killed and 18 others injured when Mexican police and 30 residents of Guerrero state clashed after the group's truck was stopped for a search. Four police officers were among those killed in the confrontation in Aguas Blancas, a town just 36km outside the Pacific resort city of Acapulco. Residents from Tepetixtla, in the southern Guerrero mountain range, opened fire on members of the motorised police who repulsed the attack. The group was on its way to a political rally and were members of a farmers organisation.</p><p>Fires menace holiday town A HUGE forest fire raging through northern Cyprus set houses ablaze in the outskirts of the holiday town of Kyrenia after ravaging an area of about 70 sq km and injuring seven people yesterday. The suburbs of the picturesque harbour town on the northern coast of the Mediterranean island were engulfed in thick smoke and several houses could be seen burning. "It's bloody awful," said Sylvia Ridley-Dash, an elderly British resident.</p><p>Plug pulled on electric chair.</p><p>A GEORGIA death-row inmate who wants to donate his organs was granted a last-minute stay of execution yesterday so a judge could hear arguments on whether the electric chair makes organ donation impossible.</p><p>US District Judge Jack Camp granted an indefinite stay two hours before the scheduled electrocution of Larry Lonchar. It was the third time Lonchar's execution was postponed just hours before it was scheduled to take place.</p><p>Politicians quit in bugging row SPANISH Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez has accepted the resignations of his deputy and his minister of defence, both victims of a bugging scandal. Deputy Prime Minister Narcis Serra and Defence Minister Julian Garcia Vargas offered their resignations after revelations that the military intelligence unit CESID had bugged leading Spanish personalities including King Juan Carlos.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4GNK-KRC0-015G-Y2N2-00000-00<published>2005-07-20T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 20</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">US</p><p nitf:lede="true">India's UN bid rejected</p><p nitf:lede="true">WASHINGTON: President George W. Bush acknowledged India's emergence as a world power on Monday but refused to endorse its bid for a seat at the Security Council at the United Nations. Mr Bush welcomed Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh to the White House for a visit that underscored his desire for closer ties to Mr Singh's nuclear-armed nation. The charm offensive included the equivalent of a state dinner, making Mr Singh only the fifth foreign leader to get the black-tie treatment since Mr Bush took office.</p><p nitf:lede="true">LESOTHO</p><p nitf:lede="true">National AIDS threat</p><p nitf:lede="true">MASERU: Lesotho will cease to exist unless it can tackle an HIV rate of about 30 per cent, former US president Bill Clinton said yesterday as he opened a clinic in the capital of the impoverished mountain kingdom. Mr Clinton, pictured, is on a six-nation tour of Africa, seeing how the AIDS pandemic is affecting children on the world's poorest continent. His foundation is spending about $US10 million ($13.4 million) on AIDS-affected children this year, mainly in rural Africa. "I ask you to help your government stop the spread of HIV/AIDS," Mr Clinton told dignitaries and local citizens after touring the hospital in Maseru. "Your country needs you. It cannot exist with 30 per cent of adults that are HIV positive."</p><p>PAKISTAN</p><p>Taliban arrests</p><p>PESHWAR: Pakistani intelligence agents had arrested five senior Taliban leaders, including a deputy to fugitive Taliban chief Mullah Mohammed Omar, security officials said yesterday. The arrests were made on Monday after security agents raided several homes in northwestern Pakistan. The officials identified two of the captured men as Maulvi Abdul Qadeer, a deputy to Omar and formerly chairman of the Taliban Special Council, and Abdul Kabir, a former governor in Afghanistan's Nangarhar province. They would not disclose the names of the remaining three leaders, but one official said "they are also important Taliban leaders who are in our custody and being interrogated in Pakistan".</p><p>SPAIN</p><p>Deadly forest blaze</p><p>GUADALAJARA: Emergency workers have evacuated the bodies of 11 volunteer firefighters who died at the weekend in a huge forest fire in central Spain, the deadliest such blaze in more than 10 years. The blaze, apparently sparked on Saturday by a barbecue and fuelled by violent winds, swept through the drought-stricken province of Guadalajara, forcing the evacuation of hundreds of people from several villages and a resort. Firefighters were still battling one of the three fronts of the fire, which extended into the Alto Tajo national park, officials said yesterday, declaring three days of official mourning.</p><p>JAPAN</p><p>Call for nuke ban</p><p>TOKYO: Japan has decided to urge the US, China, Russia and South Korea to adopt a policy to ban the use of any nuclear technology in North Korea, even for peaceful purposes, a newspaper reported yesterday. Japan hopes to present the policy at six-nation talks due this month on disarming North Korea, and make it a condition for the North to receive energy assistance, the Yomiuri Shimbun reported, citing government sources. The Japanese government has determined it would be dangerous to leave open the possibility of Pyongyang turning peaceful nuclear development to military purposes in the future, the newspaper said.</p><p>BANGLADESH</p><p>Acid attack</p><p>DHAKA: A Bangladeshi actress suffered burns when unidentified attackers threw acid at her as she left a shopping centre in the capital Dhaka, police said yesterday. The actress, who is known only as Prema, filed a complaint with police alleging her former husband and father-in-law were behind the attack, senior police officer Mohammad Akhteruzzman said. "Prema, accompanied by her housemaid, suffered burn injuries to her left hand. Her housemaid also suffered similar burn injuries," Mr Akhteruzzman said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:458W-TKR0-0197-F025-00000-00<published>1996-05-07T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>AAPINTNEWS</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">KEYWORD-HIT</p><p nitf:lede="true">Quake hits China</p><p nitf:lede="true">BEIJING: The death toll from China's latest earthquake remained at 18,</p><p nitf:lede="true">but might go higher as 280 people remained in a serious condition, a</p><p nitf:lede="true">spokesman for the Baotou Seismology Bureau said yesterday. The strong</p><p nitf:lede="true">quake, measuring 6.4 on the Richter scale, shook a mountainous valley</p><p nitf:lede="true">in the northern Chinese region of Inner Mongolia early Friday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">2000 flee blaze</p><p nitf:lede="true">TAOS, New Mexico: About 2000 residents have been forced to flee in the</p><p nitf:lede="true">face of a forest fire burning out of control in northern New Mexico.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Several homes have been destroyed but no injuries reported. The blaze</p><p>erupted yesterday afternoon and has burnt 1620ha of the Carson National</p><p>Forest.</p><p>Strike hits courts</p><p>WELLINGTON: A major trial was aborted and most courts around New</p><p>Zealand forced to close after 1400 staff walked off the job in support</p><p>of four suspended workers. The major trial involved a sexual violation</p><p>case which has been abandoned because the complainant said she would</p><p>not give evidence a second time.</p><p>Flu jabs for free</p><p>WELLINGTON: Free influenza vaccinations will be available next year to</p><p>everyone over 65, New Zealand Health Minister Jenny Shipley announced</p><p>yesterday. Flu shots currently cost $15 to $20 each. Mrs Shipley said</p><p>the main benefit of the programme would be to prevent hospital</p><p>admissions, which would ease waiting lists.</p><p>Children shot</p><p>BOGOTA: Suspected leftist guerrillas killed at least 16 people during</p><p>raids on two small towns in Colombia's north-west, an army official</p><p>said yesterday. The official said suspected members of the</p><p>Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia killed the people, some of them</p><p>children, during raids on two towns in Uraba late Sunday.</p><p>134km traffic jam</p><p>TOKYO: Millions of Japanese spent yesterday packed into cars around</p><p>the nation in the world's biggest traffic jams. The end of the annual</p><p>Golden Week series of public holidays last night produced traffic jams</p><p>up to 134km long. Train were also packed, with the Bullet Trains full</p><p>to 210 per</p><p>cent of capacity at the peak, leaving thousands of people to stand</p><p>cheek-to-cheek for up to 12 hours.</p><p>Scriptures on CD</p><p>BANGKOK: All 16,000 pages of the 2500-year-old Buddhist ""Tipitaka"</p><p>scriptures are to be published on CD ROM. About 600 monks and 1000</p><p>volunteer laymen are now putting the finishing touches on the 12-year</p><p>project. Academics and devotees in more than 20 countries have</p><p>expressed interest in the CD ROM, which will sell for $A190.</p><p>Chess titans clash</p><p>ELISTA, Russia: American grandmaster Gata Kamsky has agreed to play</p><p>the World Chess Federation's championship match in Russia, the</p><p>federation's president said yesterday. The young Kamsky will play</p><p>Russia's Anatoly Karpov for the championship in Elista, capital of the</p><p>region of Kalmykia on the Caspian Sea.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:46H0-S0V0-015G-Y1JG-00000-00<published>2002-08-13T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FINANCE; Pg. 21</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>Tony Grant-Taylor</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FOREST FIRE</p><p nitf:lede="true">SOMETIMES it can be a blessing to miss the boat.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Back late last year, Cherrell Hirst and Robin Ferris were lined up to add a bit of independent oomph to the board of retirement village developer and operator Forest Place, which has been something of a disappointment to shareholders over the past four years.</p><p nitf:lede="true">But at the meeting that was to elect them, major shareholders Frank Withey and Ray Munro decided they didn't want the two independents aboard.</p><p>Hirst and Ferris withdrew. And with hindsight, they are probably relieved.</p><p>For since, it has been all down hill for Forest Place, with its share price, which was up about $1.16 four years ago and 45 early this year now sitting at about 27 after recovering in the last little while from lower levels.</p><p>MATTER OF WILL</p><p>YOUR diarist hears that a recent mediation session did not settle the differences between the executors and beneficiaries of the will of Barry Saragossi -- and that the dispute about the extent of Barry's estate may now end up going to trial. In the meantime, it is understood that the plaintiffs' beneficiaries have been given the right to an independent assessment of G James value, due to be completed by week's end.</p><p>CALLING IT A DAY</p><p>IAN Donaldson, Queensland chairman of accountants Hall Chadwick, is calling it quits after more than 20 years with the firm.</p><p>Donaldson was the firm's local managing partner for 19 years, chairman of Hall Chadwick Australia for three years and also chairman of the Institute of Chartered Accountants.</p><p>He retains a number of directorships, including with City Pacific Group, the Leukaemia Foundation and the Mackay Sugar Co-operative Association.</p><p>BERTUS' BRIGADE</p><p>THAT old friend of City Beat, the former chief executive of Ross Mining, disco dancing Bertus de Graf, has some high-profile directors on the board of his latest vehicle, Geodynamics Ltd.</p><p>Hitching their stars to Bertus' dream of generating electricity from heat secreted in granite deep in the earth's crust is chairman Martin Albrecht, who also chairs construction and engineering group Thiess and Bob Flew, who once ran BHP Australia Coal and became BHP's company secretary.</p><p>Neil Galwey, who led the Queensland Electricity Commission and was chairman of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, and now chairs renewable energy venture capital fund CVC Reef, is also aboard -- with the boffins who know about hot rocks, Doone Wyborn and Prame Chopra .</p><p>BACK TO THE FUTURE</p><p>ANOTHER City Beat favourite, Siegfried Konig, is about to be born again -- in the corporate sense.</p><p>Siegfried's Telco Australia today becomes Future Corporation Australia having chucked in telecommunications, which proved a tough business, to become a technology and biosciences investor.</p><p>Equally tough sectors, one might think. So we will see how Future Corp -- which has investments in environmental solutions, IT services, investment advice and rare books, through an indirect stake in Brisbane's Archives Fine Books -- pans out in future.</p><p>GOING FOR BROKE</p><p>COULD stockbroking, which is pretty competitive at present, be about to get even more cut throat?</p><p>The word on the street is that Jeff Falvey, who for many years ran the Brisbane office of Ord Minnett, may be about to resurface -- with a gig at SalomonSmith Barney said to be on the cards.</p><p><email normalizedValue="mailto:citybeat@qnp.newsltd.com.au">citybeat@qnp.newsltd.com.au</email></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:49NN-3550-01S8-8192-00000-00<published>1994-12-17T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head/><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Today MAD MAX 2 (1981, M) 8.33pm NWS 9. Mel Gibson's second go as Max is a spectacular, outrageous romp bursting at the seams with action. It's mostly nonsense but all very watchable as we see Max defend a small community from a bunch of assorted ratbags and utterly ruthless hoodlums.</p><p>THE BIG AND THE BAD (1971, PG) 9pm SBS. Knockabout western comedy with Bud Spencer (real name Carlo Pedersoli) on the run from a gunfighter (Jack Palance).</p><p>RING OF FIRE (1961, M) 11.35pm NWS 9. Absurd outdoor action drama with David Janssen as an Oregon sheriff kidnapped by teenagers. He leads them into a police trap and then a spectacular forest fire to the music of Duane Eddy.</p><p>A NIGHT AT THE OPERA (1935, G) 10.55pm ABS 2. The best of the Marx Brothers, with slick gags, knockabout slapstick and very clever, hilarious episodes. Groucho is in top form as Otis B Driftwood who, with Chico and Harpo, heads for the New York Opera to help Alan Jones stay with his opera sweetheart (Kitty Carlisle).</p><p>SWEET SMELL OF SUCCESS (1957, PG) 4.15am SAS 7. An absurd time for this brilliant drama, with Burt Lancaster as a ruthless New York columnist and Tony Curtis as his errand boy who does the dirty work.</p><p>Great mood and feeling from the settings and characters.</p><p>Tomorrow THE SECRET (1992, M) 8.30pm SAS 7. The secret is something old storekeeper Kirk Douglas has with his grandson, which creates tension with his son (Bruce Boxleitner). The story's flaws are covered by the warmth of the performances.</p><p>GHOST DAD (1990, PG) 8.30pm ADS 10. Heavy-handed fantasy with Bill Cosby (directed by Sidney Poitier) as a powerhouse businessman and widower with little time for his children. When tragedy turns him into a ghost he tries to atone.</p><p>THE CHINESE LEGEND (1991) 9pm SBS. Chinese fantasy about kung-fu expert Yat Fung, who is sent by his master on a journey to learn magical powers so he can destroy the ghost king, who has pledged to take over the world.</p><p>THE FIENDISH PLOT OF DR FU MANCHU (1980, PG) 9.35pm NWS 9. Peter Sellers died shortly after completing this tired, familiar comedy. It looks a hurried effort and even the help of John LeMesurier, Stratford Johns and David Tomlinson can't lift it.</p><p>UNFAITHFULLY YOURS (1985, PG) 11.50pm ADS 10. Remake of the Preston Sturges 1948 comedy, with Dudley Moore in the Rex Harrison role as a jealous orchestra conductor who believes his young wife (Nastassja Kinski) is having an affair. This is one of Moore's better efforts since Arthur .</p><p>Outstanding.</p><p>High-quality and entertaining.</p><p>Competent and entertaining. Minor interest.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier
