urn:contentItem:4C0C-84D0-015G-Y09C-00000-00<published>2004-03-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:06:37Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FINANCE; Pg. 23</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:byline>Richard owen</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">BENDIGO BOOMS</p><p nitf:lede="true">COMMUNITY favourite Bendigo Bank, which received yet another tick from ratings agency S&P the other day by being put on positive credit watch, continues to expand in Queensland under the stewardship of state manager and budding author John Goddard.</p><p nitf:lede="true">This time the focus is on the pulsating Sunshine Coast city of Caloundra where Bendigo has just done an agency deal with local Ord Minnett franchisee Terry Murphy.</p><p nitf:lede="true">According to Goddard, who's known "Murph" for years since his Sydney days in mortgage insurance, the agency deal offered a particularly cost-effective means of quickly getting Bendigo's shingle up in the rapidly growing sea change hub.</p><p>When not attending to bank business, Goddard has been expending surplus time and energy promoting his ripping corporate thriller The General to potential publishers. No luck yet but we look forward to news of a publishing deal soon.</p><p>HOT TOPIC</p><p>RATHER than complain about the heat from looming climatic change, Central Queensland University boffin Professor Bob Miles is urging Queensland business to focus on "hot" new markets which may open up.</p><p>"It's going to be hot and dry for years to come, but the upside is that people who plan ahead can make money from everyone's discomfort," said the professor who has an upcoming lecture on the subject in Rockhampton.</p><p>Apart from increased energy demands for cooling, pest problems, land values and forest fire frequency, business needed to concentrate on the impact on cropping and grazing, aged care, and the cost of water treatment due to blue green algae.</p><p>Visionary stuff.</p><p>NIGERIAN VICTIM</p><p>THE Nigerian letter scam strikes again. This time a Melbourne financial adviser copped a lifetime ban from the industry and was committed to stand trial in the Victorian courts.</p><p>Robert Andrew Street, who operated the Box Hill-based financial planning business called Making Dollars & Sense, allegedly obtained more than $700,000 from several clients by misrepresenting the nature and risk of the purposes for which their money would be used.</p><p>ASIC has alleged that Street transferred the money to various overseas destinations after falling for a Nigerian scam letter. ASIC has also claimed Street transferred the money to various overseas destinations after receiving a proposal from a person purporting to be a representative of a Nigerian government committee who has offered to transfer $US65 million ($A87 million) to Street upon payment of certain up-front fees.</p><p>Street received the proposal from a person claiming to be Reverend Sam Kukah, Chairman of the Presidential Payment Debt Reconciliation Committee in Nigeria.</p><p>SUNNY SIDE UP</p><p>FORGET what your doctor told you 10 years ago.</p><p> Sunny Queen Farms want to set the record straight. Eggs are good for you. They're hosting an industry lunch today at Restaurant Rapide in Camp Hill to celebrate the humble egg's resurgence and provide the latest health sector findings and market statistics. Eggs will no doubt feature prominently among the dishes whipped up by celebrated Brisbane chef Paul McGivern. Now if only pork producers would get their act into gear and start spruiking the benefits of bacon -- then we'd have a completely guilt-free breakfast.</p><p>A MERE MINNOW</p><p>THERE is nothing like the release of the Fortune 500 list to put Australia's financial market in perspective. Our largest company, National Australia Bank, capitalised at $48 billion, looks like a minnow compared with US retail giant Wal-Mart. The famous retail group was named number one on the Fortune 500 list of America's largest companies for the third year in a row. It's capitalisation weighs in at a healthy $US260 billion ($A350 billion).</p><p>Tony Grant-Taylor is on leave</p><p><email normalizedValue="mailto:citybeat@qnp.newsltd.com.au">citybeat@qnp.newsltd.com.au</email></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata
